properties.Notes: by Megan Isadore:  My first sighting of river otters in Marin!  I was walking along Devil's late at night, heard rustling way down the bank and splashing, and saw 5 pairs of shining eyes reflecting back at me.  They startled when they saw/heard me, and bounded upstream until they came to a pool, where they stayed and peered up at me.  Slippery, sliding, moon-dappled beauties!

by Jonathan Toal: While in my kayak I was tying it by rope to a tree trunk that was partially in the water so that I could sit in one spot and fish. The water to my left (lake side) exploded in my face and when i turned and looked to see what caused it two adult river otters surfaced behind my kayak and looked at me. They continued to swim further in the direction of the main body of the lake.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Shell Pond, Bay Point.  August 22, 2005
properties.Notes: by Robert Rust:  These were on private property at an environmental clean up site.

by Leslie Patton:  for many years I'd take my dogs up to the Nike Missel site (now also a skateboard area) at the Las gallinas golf course/ponds. Below the missel site there is a large fresh water pond fed by underground streams. No access except through the golf course and of course the bay wetlands are nearby. Every summer for about a week I'd see two otters in the pond, eating crayfish. They'd eat their fill, then head back to the river. I always assumed they walked over the golf course to get to the ponds. I am sure they still are there frequenting those ponds. They used to play with my dogs. I didn't see this location on your spotter map so I am submitting this info to you now. These river otters have been there for many years and I am sure they will be there next summer.

by John Wall: The otter swam a circuit around the pond, investigating but having no apparent luck hunting, then exited the pond toward the west. There was enough of a trail and slide that I was able to anticipate the place of his crossing.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Petaluma River Entrance, April 7, 2010
properties.Notes: By Lorrie Foster: He was very close to the shore line in the water. He was watching us watch him, we turned off the motor to take pictures and he disappeared into the water. We saw him again on the other side of the shore, but he was too far way to photograph.

Photo available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:River_otter_Richmond_Marina_Scott_Campbell_July_29,_2010.jpg

Looks like a mom and her pups.
by George Watson: In a muddy pool, animals were playiing, squirming in and out, so fast it was impossible to count them or watch any individual.
By Tristan Brenner: Playful leading our kayaking group. Stopping on rocks, preening then jumping back in. Some very relaxed on rock observing us.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters, Corte Madera Creek, October 21, 2010
properties.Notes: By Laura Chariton:  hauled out on bank after feeding in deep creek pool.  1 adult and 2 juveniles.

properties.Description: 9 River Otters - Moorhen Marsh, Martinez.  Jan. 5, 2011
properties.Notes: by Kelly Davidson:  At this time, the otters were using a dense stand of bulrush as a mid-day haul out area. I knew they were in there so I waited for them to emerge. During my wait, several came out to the edge to defecate and then went back inside. At about 1:45 pm I started seeing otters in the water and otters emerging from the haul out. There were 9 in all. I eventually followed them around the 21 acre sight and took multiple photos.

by Aleta George: Near the downtown park is a public dock. I saw bubbles between the dock and the basin wall and followed the bubbles. Five feet below where I stood, four river otters dove to the shallow bottom and came to the surface to eat their snack, which was too small for me to identify. The eating must have been good because I watched them in this routine for 10 minutes, diving and eating and looking at me. At the end of the dock, they stretched their long necks out of the water to look at me, as if for the first time, and dove. In the middle of the basin, about 100 yards away, all four of them stretched out their necks one last time to look at me, and then they were gone! It was very exciting!

The main Suisun slough snakes through the Suisun Marsh, the largest continuous marsh in the Western US. The Suisun slough is large enough to accomodate sail and motor boats. There are numerous side sloughs throughout the system. The walls of the slough are thick with tall tule. Kayaking in the side sloughs is like slipping through green walls.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Kent Lake, Marin.  Jan 28, 2011.
properties.Notes: This is the 1st (as you head upstream) and largest reservoir on Lagunitas Creek.
Feb and Oct 2011, 2 river otters struck by cars.  In March 2012, Friends of Corte Madera Creek installed river otter crossing road signs to help protect the otters.

properties.Description: 1 DEAD River Otter - offramp to Rowland Blvd, Novato.  2 Feb, 2011.
properties.Notes: Submitted by Maggie Rufo: 2/7/11 Freshly dead river otter. Hwy 101 Northbound off-ramp to Rowland Blvd. I believe this death was caused by Caltrans putting up orange fencing all along the roadsides while they do construction. The otter could not get back into the roadside wetland area. I reported it to a Caltrans biologist.  [uc]

properties.Description: 1 River Otter -- Nunes Stock Pond PRNS -- Rich Stallcup
properties.Notes: Feb 9, 2011: 1 River Otter observed in the Nunes Ranch stock pond by Rich Stallcup on a bird count.  Rich mentioned it is the furthest west he has ever seen one before.

By David Johnston: We see them at the Valero WWT plant on Park Rd in Benicia. They swim in from Sulfur Springs Creek and fish in the rainwater ponds, which are stocked with Mosquito fish.
Last March we had three adults and 2 pups.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters, Rancho Solano Golf Course.  May 15, 2011
properties.Notes: by Kathleen Bond:  These two otters were playing wildly! I watched them for 10-15 minutes, and they were scampering in and out of the pond, and appeared to be sliding down the embankment leading to the pond's edge. I think they were eating the fish in the pond and may have come into the pond through the golf course drainage system. They stayed close together during the time I observed them. Several other people watched the otters at a range of about 20-50 feet and they seemed undisturbed by the proximity of the observers. They were frolicking and having fun! I only saw these two otters once, and I walk by the pond twice a day, nearly every day.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Beach Drive, San Rafael.  Jun 27, 2011
properties.Notes: Submitted by Tricia Rose

properties.Description: 4 River Otters, Las Gallinas Pond #2.  July 10, 2011
properties.Notes: by Peter O'Hara:  Otters swam as group about 5-20 feet from pond edge, all diving regularly. On suface the vocalised and nuzzled each other. Kept within a radius of 15 feet from each other.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Buck's Lake, Ca.  July 21, 2011
properties.Notes:
by Julie Keechler: The otter was swimming just under to surface of the water, and once in a while would stop to look around. We tried to stay far enough away as to not disturb, but close enough to observe.
It seemed as though it had swam from the entrace of one creek (left hand creek) and it was swimming toward another creek called Mill Creek.

properties.Description: 5 River Otters - White Gulch, Tomales Bay.  Sept 24, 2011
properties.Notes: While kayaking, we encountered 5 otters foraging in White Gulch. We observed them for ~1-hr feeding on fish, maybe crab (was hard to tell).  We also observed otter scat and possibly a den site.
Feb and Oct 2011, 2 river otters struck by cars.  In March 2012, Friends of Corte Madera Creek installed river otter crossing road signs to help protect the otters.

properties.Description: 9 River Otters, near Little Honker Bay, October 2011
properties.Notes: by Jim Dye: They were moving down the shoreline as a group, splashing, swimming and staying close together as a group. When they seen us in our boat they immediately left the area. They got fairly close, maybe 20 feet away or so.
Submitted by Jude Mariah: Two otters playing on the bank of Salmon Creek, running up and down into the water; also both otters out of the water grooming on the bank.

properties.Description: 4 River Otters - Green Bridge, Point Reyes Stations. Nov 4 2011
3 River Otters - Abbott's Laggon, Point Reyes National Seashore.  Nov 13, 2011.
properties.Notes:
Submitted by Sharon Barnett incl. video.
Otters observed scent-marking in the dunes, defecating and feeding on fish in the lagoon.
Video available on our website at http://www.riverotterecology.org/photo--video.html

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Coyote Creek, Tamalpais Valley. Nov 22, 2011
properties.Notes:
By Kitty Edwinson (pics below):
On November 22, 2011, at about 12:30 p.m., I saw a pair of otters swimming together in the creek, heading towards Tam Valley from Richardson Bay. Sometimes they were entwined as they swam.

When I returned from my walk, the otters were watching me and my dog from the creek across from my back fence. I ran and got my camera and took these photos. The otters did not care that I was just across the water from them. They swam under the bridge, right next to the Dipsea Cafe, with cars roaring overhead, and ate lots of fish. Then they snuggled and fussed with each other before waddling into the storm drain next to the bridge, but I have not seen them since. Here are photos of them eating fish under the bridge, cuddling, and waddling.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters on San Anselmo Creek, Fairfax.  Dec 2011.
properties.Notes: Observation by Al Balaq w. video.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Fox Pond, Healdsburg.  Dec 10-11, 2011 and Jan 13, 2012
properties.Notes:
By Emily Heaton: On December 10, 2011, my husband and I saw a river otter in Fox Pond at Healdsburg Ridge Open Space Preserver. I went back the next day to try and get some pictures. That day (Dec 11), the otter spent much of an hour energetically swimming around the pond in pursuit of food, occasionally going to shore to feast on its unfortunate victims. I just loved tracking its underwater movement by following the trail of air bubbles, and hearing its inhalations during brief trips to the surface. The highlight was watching it chow down on a big fish - I could even hear crunching! I'm not sure what else it might have been eating. A few times, it got out onto the shore and walked around briefly before going back into the pond.

I didn't return to the pond until a month later on January 13, 2012. I was surprised to find the otter at the pond. I thought it would have exhausted the food supply within a week or so. On Jan 13, the otter was eating something when I arrived, but it soon disappeared.

I talked to a woman sometime in April who said she visits Healdsburg Ridge almost every day. She said the otter was at the pond for 2 months this past winter.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Escobar Creek, Martinez.  Dec 31, 2011.
properties.Notes: Filmed by Moses Silva.  Otter utilizing beaver pond!

Submitted by David Mackenzie: Observed at Muir Beach, front lagoon.  Otters mostly submerged, occasionally surfacing for less than a minute, then down again. Seen overall for about 5 minutes by 5 skilled observers. May have been eating small fish when surfaced.

Submitted by David Cook.
River otter observed swimming in ocean at the end of the jetty. This otter is likely from the freshwater pond on Bodega Head named the Hole in the Head.

properties.Description: 1-3 River Otters, Hidden Lakes Park, Martinez. Jan. 19, Feb. 16, Feb. 27, 2012
properties.Notes:
First time they were eating fish along the shoreline, hidden among the roots and branches of overhanging trees and bushes. We confirmed 2, each had their own fish.

Second time we confirmed 3 of them swimming along the shoreline. Playing around.
Third time saw one otter swimming in middle of the lake. Lazy rolling up and down, diving, lolling, etc.
Each sighting was confirmed by others on the walk.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Dutch Bill Creek, Camp Meeker.  Jan 21, 2012
properties.Notes: by Betty Bryant: The otter was swimming downstream in Dutch Bill Creek. He or she swam under the bridge, climbed out of the water onto the river bank, and then disappeared into the bushes.

Submitted by Allyn Bissell: My observations while birding on January 24, 2012. I first saw two otters outside the water gate just west of the bridge on the Mill Valley-Sausalito path, immediately north of Sycamore Avenue at 8:34 am. Pic here

Submitted by Allyn Bissell:
Saw a single otter swimming in the Pickleweed Inlet section of Richardson Bay just off the Mill Valley Dog Park at 8:53 am. Pic here.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Spring Lake, Santa Rosa.  30 Jan, 2012.

properties.Notes:
by Al Oliver: I was crossing a bridge that crosses Novato creek from the campus. The otter was spotted swimming east towards the bridge that crosses the creek towards the dog park areas. The otter was mostly swimming beneath the surface. The creek was low and clear enough to see to the bottom.

I noticed a bubble trail in the water. As the otter approached the bridge it surface briefly and then headed towards the bank under some brush. No other behaviors were observed.

Submitted by Eric Ettlinger: One adult caught my attention by splashing upstream of where I stood. It surfaced and started eating something, probably a small fish. It then chirped (likely to the pups) before spotting me in the creek. It snorted at me a few times before submerging and swimming upstream. Later I went upstream and was crossing a log over the creek when I saw an otter swim below me underwater. Two adults were swimming around the pool before leading two pups under me and downstream.

Submitted by Jack Obedzinski:
In the outflow stream into Lagunitas Creek, just below Kent Lake. These were seen about an 1/8th of a mile upstream from Shafter Bridge on Sir Francis Drake Blvd near Samuel P Taylor State Park. A week before, two otters were seen in the large pool below the dam. Both adults.

Swimming in a large pool, and diving. All staying together. 

Stream with some deep pools. Salmon spawning in the area.

properties.Description: 4 River Otters - Abbott's Lagoon, PRNS. Feb 9 & 10, 2012
properties.Notes: 4 River otters observed feeding, playing, marking and defecating.
By Paul Olson:  saw 2 otters on bank of canal that comes down from Lake Beryessa

Submitted by Patrick Blanchard. Both otters were rooting around in the stream searching for and eating macro invertebrates and fish.

Photo here.
by David Nelson:  swimming upstream in high water; Excited about the siting called my brother immediately afterwards to tell him. I had no idea river otters would be in a creek in Marin.

By Catherine LeFevre: I have never seen an otter in real life until now -- my five year old daughter and I were THRILLED and CHARMED!!! Otters rock! We almost missed it as we were headed for the parking lot and the people we were hiking with called us back. A friend only just yesterday told me about your site or I would have reported it sooner. Thanks so much!

Submitted by Sharon Barnett.
Photo here.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Laguna de Santa Rosa Preserve, Sebastopol.  March 3, 2012
properties.Notes:
by Betsey Sanville: Swimming in the water. I first noticed the line of bubbles down the middle of the waterway. Then he popped his head up, snorted through his nose looking right at me for 30 seconds, then swam off.
Very sweet and curious.

Submitted by Josiah Clark.
Roadkill.  The second Josiah has seen, the other being near the Petaluma River.  [uc]
Reported by Jim White.
Reported by Allyn Bissell.  Swimming.
by John Paul Nepote: Walked across a gravel/dirt road from a patch of bulrush east towards Pacheco Creek.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Petaluma River, Petaluma.  15 March 2012
properties.Notes: Submitted by Paige Green.

by Elaine Aron: It was alone, playing on the pipe that crosses in front of the dam. It went over it seceral times, rubbed its face on it, dove and surfaced regularly. I couldn't figure out what it was at first, but it was definitely the right shape. But it was small and dark, so it would have been a pup alone, which might be a concern. I was so excited, so looked on the internet and here you are. And here they are! Something lovely to be thankful for today.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Redwood Creek, Muir Woods National Monument.  March 22, 2012
properties.Notes: Reported to Ranger Tim Jordan:  Otter swam downstream.

properties.Description: Otter Tracks - Indian Beach, Tomales Bay.  Mar 23, 2012
properties.Notes: Marks, tracks, possible spraint.  P. Bouley.

by Paul Lokay: The otter came out of a small, flow controlled, stream on McNear brickyard road and then went off into the bay.
It was a very low tide. Solo otter slid around in the in the mud for a minute or two, back and forth, back and forth, and then went on out into the bay

properties.Description: 2 River Otters, Phoenix Lake, Marin.  April 2, 2012
properties.Notes: By Rob Nowlain: swimming and diving

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Corte Madera Creek, Kentfield.  April 3 2012
properties.Notes: Submitted by Mia McFarland.

by Zoe Anderson: Otter seemed to be looking for food, only stayed a few minutes in that location and then swam upriver.
This was the third river otter sighting for me this year but the first single otter. I've also ways seen them in pairs.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Spring Lake, Santa Rosa.  6 April 2012.
properties.Notes: Submitted by Ruth Rudesill.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Dow Wetlands Preserve, Antioch.  April 10, 2012
properties.Notes:
By Ian Wren: Viewed a single adult along a seldom-used path in the preserve, adjacent to a creek. There were visible signs of scat, tracks and 'slides' through the mud.
Tracks were evident along the trail, along with scat and slides along the trail, which is perched on top of a narrow levee.

By Maureen Forys: The otter was running down a hill and ran across the road in front of us as we were driving on highway 1, just as you turn down the hill after crossing the Goat Rock entrance. I am relieved to say it made it safely across!

By Debra Fisher: swimming just offshore.
It's not a site that would seem like a good place for otters to spend much time. Access to the bay is blocked by sea walls and streets and there is a lot of activity at the yacht club. However I spotted an otter with pups last August in the adjacent Belvedere Lagoon and Tiburon Railroad Marsh, so they are definitely a presence in the area.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Tinsley Island, Stockton.  14 April 2012.
properties.Notes: Submitted by Steven Painter.  Swimming with prolonged dives through a small slew inside the outer levies of Tinsley Island. Otters were following each other up the slough apparently in sync, but were never closer than 20ft or so to each other while on the surface.

properties.Description: 1 DEAD River Otter - Atherton offramp, Highway 37. April 15, 2012
properties.Notes: By Roni Yarnot:  Unfortunately, appeared deceased on shoulder of road. Called Marin Humane Society for pickup.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Lake Herman, Benicia.  April 15, 2012
properties.Notes: By Cheryl Reynolds:  Otter was cruising up the creek until he realized I was there. He went through the culvert to the other side of the road where he encountered a beaver. I heard the tail flaps twice and heard a lot of commotion and some squeals. I saw a beaver in the creek for a minute and watched lots of ripples for a few minutes before the otter reappeared and came back under the culvert.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Cache Creek Regional Park.  April 15, 2012
properties.Notes: By Scott Eldredge:  otters swimming along creek

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Corte Madera Creek.  April 24, 2012
properties.Notes: By Peter Hogg:  just swimming along.

properties.Description: 4 Otters Crossing Road - Nicasio Reservoir.  Apr 25 2012.
properties.Notes: 4 otters crossing the road adjacent to Nicasio Reservoir just before stop sign on Point Reyes Petaluma Rd.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters, Ellis Lake Park, Concord.  April  27, 2012
properties.Notes: by Robert Pratt:  swimming, chasing fish

properties.Description: Otter Tracks and Scat - North of Pita Beach.  April 29, 2012
properties.Notes:
by Paola Bouley
Tracks, scat

By Emily Heaton: In the early morning, I was down by the lake watching birds when all of a sudden, some nostrils popped up in the water about 25m away, near a partially submerged snag. Soon, I saw 3 river otters surface. They didn't seem interested in being near me and took off swimming down the lake, in close proximity to each other. Every once in awhile, I would see them surface, but I soon lost track of them. They all seemed to be the same size and were definitely traveling together.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Rush Creek, Novato, May 6, 2012
properties.Notes: By Adam Donkin:  swimming and diving
By Gary Leo:  The Otter was noisily eating a fish, in the bushes at the edge of the lake.  I took pictures, but nothing is clear.
By Gary Leo:  eating a fish
By Gary Leo: It was in the water noisily eating something for several minutes. I assume it was a fish.
By Charles Fonseca:  I see them twice a year, for about 2 years now.  They like deep water under the bridge.

by Sally McFadden: The otters where swimming around one another, twirling and wrestling. They dove repeatedly, coming to the surface eating what appeared to be crayfish. I could hear loud crunching and smacking sounds. One had a very light grey throat and breast. The otters were about 20 yards from shore. The one with the grey breast raised her head high out of the water and looked at me a couple of times.
5-7 week old pup, rescued by kayaker, to Lake Tahoe for rehabilitation and future release

properties.Description: 2 DEAD river otter pups Larkspur.  May 27, 2012
properties.Notes: 2 pups found drowned near where the single pup was found.
Foraging and actively feeding on crayfish, fish and frogs - resting briefly on logs to eat prey.
by Jared Huffman: Large bass exploded out of the water in the jaws of an otter - very cool to see.
One river otter, fishing in the lagoon.

by Sarah Codde: Three of them were rolling around eachother in the edge of the pond and the other two were doing the same. It basically looked like two balls of otters. I only observed them for about 5 minutes as I had to move on. All of the otters seemed similar size.
By Pete Cahalen: in the Marina at the Aeolian Yacht Club. Just saw it swimming in the marina ,never saw it again. Noone at the Yacht club has ever seen an otter on the bay or near our yacht club.
by Jeanna Aydelotte:  Spotted otter running across a paved section of the dam towards the lake

by Monica Schwalenberg-Pena:  First I saw the adult's head sticking out of the water, it was making growly sounds, then it dove with that beautiful sinuous movement, arch of back, tail; then I saw a mini version right next to it, making beep sounds like the sea otter babies do. They swam into the tules.  One adult and one really cute baby!

by Leslie Hoey: The otter was swimming and diving, looking under rocks. Then he/she would swim under an overhang of concrete.

I have seen him 3 times. Once at daybreak and twice in the evening at dusk. The last time I though there were two of them but it was too dark to tell.

I get a lot of wildlife back there because on the otherside of the creek is a school and it's very quiet.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Tomales Bay Oyster Company.  July 3, 2012
properties.Notes: by Peter White: One otter was swimming and diving among oyster farming operation. We talked to an Oyster worker who said the otter(s) were frequently seen.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters, Muir Woods National Monument.  July 4, 2012
properties.Notes: by Ranger Tim Jordan:  They looked like medium otters (both the same size), so we couldn't tell if they were mature or juvenile. What was rather exciting was they went inside the biggest redwood (across creek from Willian Tell Tree) and stayed inside for a couple of minutes before coming back out and resuming play. A den in there possibly?

by Gerry Jalocki: Floating boat house used nearly nightly in the past.
Today marks the return after at least 2 months

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Gravenstein Highway near Stony Point Rd.  July 7, 2012
properties.Notes: by Susan Soiland.  Saw a river otter swimming across pond.
by Gordon Beebe:  2 pups following an adult in the Bay.

A river otter on a mission....running up from the water toward the pilings under Nick's Cove restaurant.  Dogs began barking at it, and it turned and ran back to the water.  It swam around observing the beach for a few minutes, then swam away.

I noticed some odd disturbance on the surface of the Seadrift lagoon and slowly paddled my stand up paddleboard closer to observe what it was. As I approached, one otter dove and I saw its tail. I stopped and waited for them to resurface, which they did, much closer to my board than before. They were feeding when I first noticed them. When they resurfaced, one had caught and was eating a small crab. It ate with its body vertically in the water, head up and nose pointed toward the sky, smashing the crab with its sharp teeth while the other otter watched. When they noticed me, they ducked under the water and resurfaced about 20-30 feet away. They wrestled together, resurfacing and ducking under to swim, much like seals. At one point one resurfaced with a small fat fish and ate it much like the crab--body vertical in the water and nose pointed skyward, chomping on the fish. I saw this happen twice. The two otters swam together the entire 10-15 minutes I observed them, and eventually I lost track of them.

by Tim Ridges: I have spotted otters in different locations on lake Sonoma for three years in a row.

Last summer I spotted a group of 6 cruising around in front of skunk creek campground at sunrise for 2 consecutive mornings.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Coyote Hills Park, Fremont.  July 18, 2012
properties.Notes: by Jerry Ting, beautiful photo attached.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Macama Creek, Sonoma.  July 19, 2012
properties.Notes: by Don Loarie
by Andrea Dougall (otter keeper at Oakland Zoo):  1 adult, 3 juveniles, Foraging and feeding, vocalizing (chirps and grunts)

properties.Description: 6 River Otters, Point Reyes National Seashore, July 21, 2012
properties.Notes:
by Ally Nauer:  Playfulness on sand dunes for about 5 minutes. Rolling in sand. One otter came up after others.
Laid fresh scat on dunes (fish scales in scat)

Went back into water, swimming East (towards trailhead)

All otters looked about same size - unable to tell adults vs. older juveniles.
by Rose Martin:  Playful and preening.  They've been here for at least 3 years.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters - Las Trampas Creek, Walnut Creek.  July 22, 2012.
properties.Notes: by Lisa Ryan: Rolling around and playing together. Sliding into the water from the bank. Rolling over in the water and swimming.
by Geoff Logan: Crossing Livorna Road in Alamo just before the freeway normal toward San Jose. They went under the fence toward the the creek.

properties.Description: 6 River Otters - Alhambra Creek, Martinez.  July 26, 2012
properties.Notes:
by Cheryl Reynolds: the group of otters were cruising up and down the creek at super high tide. 6 otters were observed coming out on land under the bridge for a few minutes. they looked small and it was pretty quick an hard to see if there was an adult with them.
They came downstream and were chased by beavers!!
One must have gotten separated right past the dam he was making some distress cries for a short while.

There was at least one adult and at least two pups. Pretty sure the fourth one was an other adult but we had no binoculars and we had a hard time keeping track of the quick little bodies. They chirped a lot at the dog as they swam along the beach but were very relaxed once they hauled out on the rocks. They were still pretty far off shore.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Red Oak Victory Shipt, Richmond.  July 29, 2012
properties.Notes: by Gabriel Gonzalez: I and 5 of my friends visited the Red Oak Victory ship in Richmond after lunch. But it was closed so we walked towards the benches that are by the stern of the ship. We observed a river otter as we looked over the edge of the fence, it was eating and searching by all the sea vegetation that was growing on the concrete walls and ledges. The otter observed us and began to stare at us for 5 secounds and them submerged about 5ft then came back up and gazed at us for 7 secounds. But it felt as if it was expecting us to feed him. Then he submerged again and we did not see him anymore. Truly an amazing sight in the Bay.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters - Kehoe Beach, Point Reyes.  August 1, 2012
properties.Notes: by Scott Davidson:  I only observed their track and sign. 3 otters traveled from beach to mini-lagoon, marked, scat and slid (from sign), then I imagine they continued upstream.

There were 2 swimming and playing for about half an hour. My pictures did not come out great, they were too far away. There made noises, that is how I knew there were otters. The creek is beyond my backyard. It has been 2 years since I saw otters here.

by Lisa Johnson: I was walking around duck pond, and a river otter followed me (he was swimming) for about 150-200 feet. He kept popping up and looking at me, and seemed to be keeping pace with me. West side of pond, near the island where they hold the concerts during Marin County Fair.

by Gina Farr:  Heard the chirping begin upstream and watched the otter run/walk in creek past my house. Chirping stopped only momentarily as s/he scampered below us and continued on downstream. Seemed to be a solo contact call with no response heard.

Otter didn't stop at our fish pool but was on the move.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters, Oak Grove Road, Walnut Creek.  Aug 7, 2012
properties.Notes: by Norah Molina: One otter dove into the canal then came to the surface with 2 more otters. They went back underwater and swam away.

properties.Description: 5 River Otters = White Gulch, Tomales Bay.  August 8, 2012
properties.Notes: by Julie Woodruff: They were rolling around in the water, swimming.They eventually came out of the water, lingered near shore for a bit and disappeared into some brush.

properties.Description: 1 DEAD River Otter - Olivera Rd, Concord.  Nov. 8, 2012
properties.Notes: http://claycord.com/2012/11/08/river-otter-found-dead-near-pixieland-on-olivera-road-in-concord/
by Dave Cook:  3 juvenile river otter diving and feeding on fish or crayfish.

by Carlo:  In the pond, I watched a flock of gulls land, then heard the strangled bugling of Tule Elk. I watched the elk for a bit then heard the flock take off. Strange, they had just landed. Scanning back, I saw one gull in the water but it was upside-down, legs straight up in the air and belly visible. Then a river otter popped up and eventually worked it over to the far side before taking it underwater.
by Claire Peaslee:  crossing the road

properties.Description: 3 River Otters - Mokolumne River/Bear River confluence.August 21, 2012
properties.Notes: by Ethan Miller:  One adult, two juveniles, none very large. Observed swimming upstream through a pool in the river, periodically popping up and checking us out on the far river bank (about 30 years away at the nearest point). Last observed approaching a section of rapids.
by Stephen Orosz:  In the water on the western shore of Marina Bay near the launch ramp.

by Claudia Hein:  Spotted two river otters together just off shore not too far before the Audubon Ranch parking area. I remember thinking upon immediate view that they must be Harbor Seals, but then noticed the faces and tails... So although our vehicle was driving at the normal speed for that area, I was in the front passenger seat (on the lagoon side) and am 99 % sure of what I saw. The time was midday around 11:45 am. Looking at the tides for that date - high tide had past but would have been just receding... Which agreed with the bird activity at the time...

properties.Description: 4 River Otters, Rodeo Lagoon, Headlands.  August 28, 2012
properties.Notes: by Randall Finley:  One biting anothers tail, one wrestling with another biting it on the neck, wrestling in the water, eating several fish
by Cassandra DeWood:  Played on beach. Rolled around. played in small creek draining into bay for 15 minutes. at dusk. maybe got scared and moved on in bay north.

by Leslie Hoey:  The Mom swam from the upper waterfall area down to below my deck. Pecked its head up at me, looked at me then swam back close up to the side of the creek.

The night before I watched the baby catch a fish and eat it.

by Anthony Brewer:  Otters spotted swimming around inland edge of lower lagoon, crossed to upper lagoon under bridge, stopped briefly to roll (and defecate) on sandy bank, then set off swimming directly across upper lagoon.
by Arvid Ekenberg: Rapidly crossing a narrow levee [
by Krista Fechner: Saw an otter swimming and diving around in the water for several minutes while we were kayak camping on the beach.
by Jules Evens: Two apparent adults (full grown) swimming upstream in tandem in the tidal slough, rooting in the substrate and under the bank on the marsh edge, apparently foraging.
by Nathan Adachi:  they were swimming

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Home Bay entrance.  Sept 16 2012
properties.Notes: by Payette Caldwell: Playing in the water at the mouth of a small cave opening exposed by the low tide. Occasionally running into the cave, then returning to the water.

by Adam Messner: I observed them for about 1 minute. They were swimming at slow speed. 50% of their time was spent crusing on the surface looking around and at me and the other 50% was spent cruising the bottom and exploring in rocks. They were regularly brushing against at and below the surface - all three staying in close contact.

properties.Description: 4 River Otters - Drake's Beach Pond.  Sept 20, 2012
properties.Notes: by Susan Kelly: I was there birding with a friend and we saw 4 otters swimming near the edge of the pond. There were 2 groups of 2 otters each.

by Kate Symonds: The river otter was periscoping in a patch of Ludwigia (nonnative aquatic weed). It appeared to be foraging, but I couldn't see any prey items. There were a lot of kayakers floating past and it seemed the otter was aware of their presence.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Drake's Beach Pond.  Sept 23 2012
properties.Notes: by Jules Evens: Two apparent adults foraging in and beneath emergent vegetation in this man-made pond which is trimmed with a dense shoreline of bulrush
by Brian Andrews:  They were jumping in and out of the water and playing.

by Lisa Johnson: Rolling and playing together in the shallow shoreline water. They noticed me sneaking up to them in a kayak and disappeared under water. I believe they swam back behind some bushes that were growing in the water and I could hear them like chirping to each other but never saw them again.

by Sara Scanlan: There was only one otter and it was swimming and eating while several people watched. At one point he/she came out of the water onto a wall edge and looked about and then slipped back into the water.
by Shane King:  Diving, looking around rolling.
by Nancy Woltering:  He was in the back yard then moved into the front yard.  It was exciting for me and my stepsons to see him!

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - San Pablo Reservoir, Orinda.  Oct. 5, 2012
properties.Notes:
by David Schatzki:  Two otters playing in Lafayette Reservoir (East side of Reservoir), Lafayette, CA
Single otter in Preserve Area of San Pablo Reservoir (south End of reservoir)

by Karlyn Lewis:  We saw the otter ahead and to our left towards the side of the slough. He went under water and then surfaced 8-10 ft from our kayak. He did a double take when he saw us, and dove under again. He surfaced on the side of the slough to our right (where I got the photo) and then he disappeared into the tules.

by Petra Nelson: 2 were swimming eastwards in the creek, and one was loping along on the bank in the same direction. They all appeared to be about the same size.

River otters in Danville, who'd a thunk it!

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Spring Lake, Santa Rosa.  Oct. 15, 2012
properties.Notes: by Tom Reynolds:  2 Otters were Hunting in the reeds.  I waited to take photos both otters came our of the reeds looked at me and kept hunting then swam to the other side of the lake.

by Christina Perez: There's a storm canal behind the Target/Toys R Us shopping center which is on Contra Costa Blvd. in Pleasant Hill. My apartment is across the canal and I see them every now and then. It looks more like a creek. There's a lot of other wildlife, egrets, various ducks, king fishers, heron, geese, racoons sometimes and deer.
They're so cute. One time one was in the parking lot behind the Target store and it looked like he couldn't find his way back into the canal. I was heartbroken. He kept running back and forth.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, D Ranch Pond.  Oct. 24, 2012
properties.Notes: by Tim Bernot:  swimming and diving

properties.Description: 1 River Otter.  Matheny Way, Citrus Heights.  Oct. 26, 2012
properties.Notes:
by Ken Maggy: Swimming and feeding, very active in and briefly out of the water.
Observed for possibly 10 minutes. It was not bothered by my presence.
Have never seen a river otter in the area before. Been working at the location for nearly three years. May wild turkeys in the neighborhood too.
by Jeffrey O'Brien:  We saw one playful otter around noon.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters - Brush Creek, Santa Rosa.  Nov 6, 2012
properties.Notes: by Stephen Hillard: Brush creek, just north of the highway 12 crossing. The pools are a little deeper there. There were three, one quite small, and two larger ones, one of which was larger by perhaps 1/3. They were originally swmming about and I just saw two, the smaller one staring at me for quite some time. Later, around 3, when I was biking home, they were on a bank walking about, and the pup was there. They seemed curious, then slowly swam off. I was only perhaps 25 feet away.
by Lidia D'Amico: The river otter was swimming with its head above the water and occasionally diving for about 15 minutes in the bath house pond.
by Kevan Vander Wahl: I've been coming here for years, and this was my first time seeing these beautiful animals!

by Richard James: Otter was hauled out on a rock. Once I saw it, it slithered into the water and swam away from me.

It appeared to be a young animal by size.

by Rebecca Doidge: The four otters were swimming across the lagoon towards the western end near the footbridge. They swam in an undulating fashion, arching their backs and bobbing their heads up and down out of the water. They stayed close together, but there wasn't any remarkable interaction between individuals. We saw them again about 1/2 hour later and they were swimming back across the lagoon in the opposite direction with same behavior as before.
by David Mackenzie:  "Playing in lagoon and resting on rock for total about 15 minutes"
by Robert Aguilar:  Moving through mixed vineyard/hilly grazing land, stopping frequently.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Eagle Vines Golf Course, Napa.  11 Nov 2012
properties.Notes: by Robert Stasko:  2 otters swimming in the pond.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Blue Rock Spring Golf Course.  11 Nov. 2012
properties.Notes: by Steve Stewart:  Swimming and feeding in the pond

properties.Description: 1-2 River Otters - Drake's Beach Pond, Nov 12, 2012
properties.Notes: 20 minutes), and suddenly an otter appeared directly below where I was perched on a hillside some 10 feet above the water's elevation.
by Jorgen Blomberg: Swimming and frollicking in a large pool (beaver dam); bubble blowing; curious observation of river survey team; single adult with five juveniles.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Larkspur Ferry Landing.  Nov 14, 2012
properties.Notes: by David Ford:  Feeding along riprap in the shadow of the statue of Sir Francis Drake.
by Dennis Olson: They were all near the same size, and hard to tell which were young. All were actively diving, catching and eating fish
by Karlyn Lewis: Wide slough lined with tules. They were swimming in an area that has buoy markers for rocks beneath the water.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Las Gallinas Sanitary Ponds, San Rafael.  Nov 18, 2012
properties.Notes: by Kate Garay:  A pair swimming together, diving, surfacing, circumnavigating pond #2.

by Jean Berensmeier: 3 young otters came out from brush climbed down a steep rock face and played in the pond below the first Inkwell pool. They were playing, swimming and catching and eating crawdads. The three them jumped into the pool with the two spears sticking out and repeated their play, swimming and eating. They jumped in to the next shallow pool and then into the large pool under the bridge playing the whole time. ?They then went up the fast running finger of water until they disappeared under the brush tht is east of the bridge just before the quiet stretch of San Geronimo Creek. Soon the appeared and went down each pool repeating the play activity. I heard several sharp calls from an adult but the three ignored the calls. When the got down to the bottom pool to my amazement they repeated their routine at each pool. Their play was a lot of tumbling together.
by Al Pisciotta:  otters were chasing a steelhead, jumping out of the water.  They did not catch it.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Stafford Lake, Novato.  Nov. 19, 2012
properties.Notes: by Sarah Lucchesi: The otter was eating then dove into the water and swam from our boat to the island. When we were almost done with our work, we noticed it was snacking on a dead mallard
by Carl Polesky:  otter playfully swimming around
by Pam Ross: Swimming around a rocky point. One otter caught and ate a fish. All 4 swimming together and squeaking a lot.
by Karlyn Lewis: Swimming and/or playing in the slough. At one point they all climbed up onto a levee or higher area out of the water.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Muir Woods Nat'l. Monument.  Nov 23, 2012
properties.Notes: by Jonathan Lyon: There was a logjam just under and upstream from the bridge and upstream which forced salmon to jump out of the water to continue upstream. The salmon were large, approximately 1 1/2 to 2 feet long. We saw two of them at least In the space of 30 minutes. At one point the otter jumped in after one and chased it for about 100 feet as it swim upstream. I don't have a picture of the otter. But I did capture a picture of the salmon that he was after. I include it below.
by Dave Mackenzie:  diving and feeding

by Parker Pringle:  Just surfaced twice and disappeared. It was a about 10 feet from the gate to the ferry dock, swimming in lights that line the ramp. Easy to see its shape clearly--its long tail etc. I have caught perch in this spot before, seen jack smelt swimming here. Also there are brown rockfish here too. MAybe herring this time of year.

by Ruth Rudesill: The Otters were on a sand bar along the lakeshore near the bridge. The adult would go into the water and the grebes would scatter! The juveniles stayed on the sand bar but were playing and rolling with each and the adult. When the adult went back on the sandbr the juveniles tackled it (her?) and rolled around. Later they were all sleeping.

by Walter Wieners: All four climbed up on to our pier which has 5 slips. They were moving quickly and examining something on the pier. %-7 seconds passed while I pulled out my iPhone, just that quick, one drank fresh rain water from a small boat on the pier and other three jumped back in the bay (see photos).
by Karlyn Lewis:  Swimming and playing.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters - Penny Lane Ponds, Napa.  December 2012
properties.Notes: by Denise Layten: They eat fish and crayfish. Before Christmas, one day there were three. Maybe a family as one looked smaller than the other two. The three swam and played together. When it's just one, s/he dives and eats. In years past, I've seen them coming to one pond and leaving from the thick blackberry bushes on our property. There is a willow tree with quite a tangle of roots in the pond, and often I've seen them among the roots. They go there to rest.
by Jules Evens
by Thomas Muehleisen: Appeared angry at my appearance. Showing teeth. The trail area that I was on is near an embankment where I have observed scat and they may have wanted to come out of the water.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Las Gallinas Creek, Terra Linda.  4 Dec 2012
properties.Notes: by Christian Naventi: The river otter swam undisturbed down the creek, heading towards McInnis Park

by Parker Pringle: 1st sighting: This was just upstream of the bridge that crosses devils gulch which has the red salmon crossing sign. Saw an otter swim upstream and meet another otter, then they both went upstream. One went upstream over a riffle and the other, surfacing, did a u-turn and went downstream, on the surface, chirping, with it's head up out of the water, looking back and forth, going about a walking pace or a little faster. Went downstream maybe 300 feet like that before I gave up following it.

2nd sighting: came around a corner and heard an almost cat like growl--mwrah mwrah. Two sounds like that. But loud. WAlked upstream a bit and I heard loud splashing sounds. Three or four in quick succession. In my imagination I pictured a bobcat leaping into the water after a salmon. Came downstream to see what I could see and saw the otter eating a large red male (With a kype) salmon. It was eating the area behind the gills.

by Chip Kaplove:  I was bicycling north on Rt 1 and had just passed Cypress Grove when one river otter crossed Rt 1 from east to west right in front of me. It was a brief interaction but absolutely no question it was a rapidly moving river otter - appeared adult size.
by Trace Kannel:  playing, swimming

by Julie Barnes: The otter swam across the creek, coming very close to a pair of mallards but not touching them. The ducks left anyhow.
I saw no actual diving, just a couple of head over heels turnarounds.

I watched for less than five minutes, until the otter swam into a cattail clump at the edge of the creek.

by John Condon: At site #1 they foraged in the water next to the bank with quite a bit of grasses growing next to the water. This is the spot where a small tributary from the town of Tomales enters Walker Creek. They stayed at this one spot for about 7 minutes and rarely swam into the main channel. I observed two small silver fish caught and eaten while in the water. They made a lot of noise in the water by splashing and rooting around the bank. They were aware of me as I sat on the opposite bank but did not seem concerned. They did not rest, preen, or go onto dry land very often as they seemed pretty intent on foraging. They then continued downstream and I left knowing that I would be able to observe them at site #2.

As you stand on the bridge at site #2 you can see upstream for about 400 yards. There is little vegetation/cover at the waters edge. As the otters swam and forgaged toward me they stayed in the deep water on the bank nearer to Hwy 1. As I was standing on the bridge in plain view they were aware of me but did not seem concerned and would float about 20 yards from me uptream of the creek and look at me. Each time they would dive to forage as they surfaced they would look at me and float on the surface. They appeared to be foraging for crabs rather than fish at site #2. I did not have binoculars so it was difficult to see what they were eating but they would often surface chewing something. They stayed at site #2 for 10 minutes and then swam upstream foraging as they swam.

I did not observe any voice communication between them and I was suprised as to how white the fur on the lower neck and upper belly was.

I believe these are juvenile otters possibly siblings

by Jonathan Koehloer: These otters appeared to have a den or hiding spot in a large debris jam on the bank of the Napa River near a site we were measuring for salmon spawning conditions. The otters were wary of our presence and vocalized several times before swimming off.
by Jorgen Blomberg: Adult otter exiting mainstem channel and walking up small tributary/drainage channel.

by Constantine Bogios: Here's the deal, I was back at the school DVC to visit some old teachers of mine and they have what they call the duck pond in the center of campus - it was a friday so hardly anyone was on campus. Anyway, two otters are hanging out swimming around in the pond. I made a squeaking noise and one looked at me and then they went on about there business and so did I. There are a lot of water ways around the city of Concord I'e seen turtles, water fowl and a red fox out there so perhaps some otters wandered into campus.

by Frank Coppel: The otters were swimming together, heading west towards the ocean. The went around the bend to the north and we lost sight of them. As they progressed, they disturbed several rafts of ducks that were floating on the water, though they didn't seem to be actively pursuing the ducks.
by Tom Gaman: Swimming in center of Narrow Reservoir, the otter had a very visible white throat. It was a large one.

by Connor Ross: The otters have been swimming to and fro within Fryer Creek, in the City of Sonoma, for several weeks (12/1 - present). They have been foraging from the creek bottom and were very active. We observed the otters out of the water a few times.

During these sitings, we observed the otters feeding on turtles on the creek bank. They were gnawing on the turtles, trying to break through the shell. The otter swam away with the turtle before we could observe it breaking through the shell.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Santa Rosa Creek.   18 Dec 2012
properties.Notes: by Quinn Donovan:  Playing. diving . looking for food. in the creek

by Jeff McCoullough: The three river otters were traveling/swimming together upstream. There were many salmon as well due to recent rains. Further upstream they exited the water briefly to run along the bank to circumvent rocks that were across the flow of the water.

by Jeff McCullough: The three river otters were traveling/swimming together upstream. There were many salmon as well due to recent rains. Further upstream they exited the water briefly to run along the bank to circumvent rocks that were across the flow of the water.

by Karen Cook:  Exited water at floating dock. Ran up gang plank to deck. Ran south to next property. Neighbors in that property report that the otters ran along their deck and out to the floating dock and re-entered the water. We saw them swimming periodically in the lagoon in back of the property.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters - Hidden Valley Lake, Ca.  December 23, 2012
properties.Notes: by Marianne Kuzminskiene: They swim eating small fish in river and then seem to have built a nest in the bank across from our home. Last year there was just one which we could not distinguish from male or female this year there are three. We see them either early morning or later in the day. Last year the one move plant life etc. building up an area that we think it is living in. I was told that someone trapped and moved this otter but this year we have three so maybe the one came back with friends or it's pups. They will sun themselves on the tree branch in the water and play. We have named them but don't know their sex, they are Timothy, Ben and Addy. My teenagers see them more because they are in our sun room reading or playing my daughter sees them go under the road and into the little lake across the way and then come back. We love these and would like for them to be protected in our area. What can we do to do so?

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Warm Springs Fish Hatchery.  30 Dec 2012
properties.Notes: by Denise Cadman:  Foraging for migrating steelhead in the fish ladder.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - McInnis County park, San Rafael.  30 Dec, 2012.
properties.Notes: by Deborah LaFleur: This otter was swimming in the direction towards railrood tracks and residences. The site isn't particularly clean (lots of garbage ends up along the banks of this creek from athletic events and general littering). Although I am extremely excited about seeing this kind of wildlife here, I am also very concerned since this area is densely populated, there are dogs running free in the park and the adjacent airport is trying to expand by building a large indoor athletic facility on its land (along parking lots). The nearby railroad tracks are also being construction for the Marin/Sonoma SMART Train.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Heather Farm Park, Walnut Creek.  31 Dec 2012
properties.Notes: by Sandy Oliver:  They were swimming under the fountain like an Esther William's movie and lounged on a floating plant island. One of them noticed me and was curious and swam up to check me out. Other than that, they appeared happy and in paradise. It was a beautiful and enchanting experience. My first response was that its face looked just like a sea otter. I saw their tails and thought they were muskrats. The reason I know they are river otter's is because on channel 7 news this morning they reported about one spotted by the Cliff House in San Francisco so I was able to positively identify them. Also, on the news they said that they can live in fresh and salt water which was why I questioned if they were muskrats to begin with and now I know they are not. This is my first sighting in my life and I have lived in the Valley my whole life and I was born in 1962. Thanks for this site and the hardwork. When I have m

properties.Description: 1 DEAD River Otter - Petrified Forest Rd, Napa.  1 Jan 2013
properties.Notes:
by Margaret Johnston-Gee:  Hit by car/DOA. Adult male, 15-20 lbs, well-fleshed, good coat condition. Rigor set in.

Individual was not there when I drove through at 1745 PM yesterday (31 December 2012). Did not see any other individuals. Moved him off the road into brush at side of road.

by Leif Bryant: actively feeding on pray, swimming, hunting.
two adults and one younger that was chirping. they were enjoying a log jam/debris at high tide

properties.Description: 3 River Otters, Shelter Bay, Mill Valley.  1 January 2013
properties.Notes: by Walt Wieners: ery low tide so they decided not to jump on boat docks and headed out of lagoon with three alternative directions, Richardson Bay, Tennessee Valley or Mill Valley Creek. In the water the whole time. During the last visit there were four as reported.
By Tom Reynolds: At "A Place to Play Resevoir."

properties.Description: 5 Otters - Hiddenbrooke Golf Course, Vallejo. January 1, 2013.

properties.Notes: by Sarah Codde: It was swimming around very close to the shore. I only watched it for about 2 minutes.

by Karlyn Lewis: Jim Lewis: I was kayaking in the late afternoon. Spotted 4 otters on bank to my right--2 adults, 2 smaller juveniles. Largest adult spotted me and swam across the slough in front of me, barking to get my attention while the other 3 otters disappeared into the tules where I could hear them crashing around. The (presumably) male otter would look directly at me, even raising his head and neck way up out of the water when barking to be sure I was following him away from the others. When he reached the opposite bank (my left), he made a final bark and disappeared under water.
by Jonathan Koehler:  swimming, feeding on fish

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Lake Anza, Tilden Park, Berkeley.  5 Jan 2013
properties.Notes: by John Kenny:  Watched it for about 10 minutes while it was swimming and diving near the shore, 20-50 yards away.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter -Llano Rd,  Santa Rosa.  Jan 6, 2013
properties.Notes: by Lisa Seale
by Jules Evens
by Melanie Piazza

properties.Description: 4 River Otters - American Canyon, Napa River Trail.  14 January, 2013
properties.Notes: by Byron Rosenberger: first time seen otters in wild was pretty surprised . i was walking my dog she noticed them first and we sat on the bench and watched for 30 min or better.

properties.Description: 4 River Otters, Heather Farm, Walnut Creek.  14 Jan, 2013
properties.Notes: by Glenn Hori: There were at least four and possibly five otters actively feeding. They kept swimming back and forth along the length of the pond, catching numerous fish in the process. At one point one otter got onto a tree trunk so that he could dine on a large fish without swimming.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, McInnis Park area, San Rafael.  16 Jan. 2013
properties.Notes: by Sue Mace: Otter was walking in the weeds parallel to the creek, then it went into the creek and swam upstream where I lost sight of it.

by Amy Trainer:  right as we came upon the bridge the otter family was swimming toward us, so north from the bridge, and then get out of the water on the mud flats and played for a minute, then kept swimming. It was low tide so it was easy to see them.
by Robert Pratt:  swimming in Lake Ellis Park

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Lake Ellis Park, Concord.  17 Jan 2013
properties.Notes: by Robert Pratt:  Swimming in the lake. Saw me with my dog, made chomping noises and then swam away. Surfaced two more times and went further away each time it spotted me.

properties.Description: 1 DEAD River Otter, Lakeville Rd.  Jan. 18, 2013
properties.Notes: by Jules Evens.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Meadow Club Golf Course.  23 Jan, 2013
properties.Notes: by David Sexton: The otter was sighted at the irrigation pond at the Meadow Club golf course. After the otter was sighted it came out of the pond, crossed a concrete cart path and headed into a thicket of willows at it went toward Bon Tempe Creek. There have been other signs of the otter's presence but this was the first sighting in many years.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Civic Center Lagoon, San Rafael.   24 Jan 2013
properties.Notes: by Jeff Wong: Not sure how the river otter found its way to this lagoon, but there is a water course (las gallinas)nearby.

properties.Description: 3 River Otters, Hole in the Head.  Jan. 25, 2013
properties.Notes: by Marcia Johnson: Swimming around, moving up & down together. There was one very nervous Pied-billed Grebe & several nervous Coots - several few away, but 3-4 stayed on land the whole time I was there (approx. 1/2 hour)

by Emily M: Following far shore, swimming under water until it reached each over hanging tree with pea-like pods. At the trees it surfaced and at the pods. Coughed once. Hope it was just fiber. Noisy eater.
by Steve Gerstle

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Los Gatos Creek County Park, Los Gatos.  January 29, 2013
properties.Notes:
by Helen Daley: I was out birdwatching late afternoon just before sunset. I was walking along the Los Gatos Creek bike trail and noticed this animal swimming in the corner of the lake (there are a number of ponds here adjacent to the lake called Oka Ponds). At first I thought it was a tortoise, but when viewing with my binocculars and saw it dive under, it definitely was not a tortoise. I have not seen anything like it before.
Notice animal swimming with head only out of water, then it dived under and I saw its tail was thick, tapering to a point, (the whole body appeared streamline. It then popped its head out of the water again, swam another 10 feet then dived under water again close to approaching some tall dead elephant grass on the bank of the lake. After researching online to determine what it was, I am sure it had to be a river otter. It was about the size of a domestic cat. From what I read online and at your site, this otter may be around for a while because it will have a good food supply, clean water and vegetation in this location.
by Karlyn Lewis: Swimming. He dove under water before we could take any photos, and although we watched and waited, we didn't see him again.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Hiddenbrook Golf Course, Vallejo.  Jan. 31, 2013
properties.Notes: by Jamie Ross:  Sighted in the pond at the fifth hole at the Hiddenbrook Golf course in Vallejo. It lies at the top of Sky Valley and drains into Lake Herman. I've seen otters in this vacinity on numerous occasions. There is an active Beaver pond down stream of the golf course where I've seen up to four otters at a time. 2 adults and two juveniles. In this location I regularly see muskrat, beaver and otters. I am a wildlife biologist and, as such, am confident of my identification.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters - Corte Madera Creek.  Feb. 1 2013
properties.Notes: by Peggy Fledderjohn: One otter was swimming in the narrow part of the stream/canal area out towards where it opens up into the widest part of the stream. It swam and dove for a while and then met up with another otter and they both went onto land, first onto a cement outcropping, and shook themselves. They then dove back in the water. I saw one later on and it had apparently gone through a drainage pipe/culvert into a small connecting creek and was swimming near the bank. Made my day as I was able to see both of them quite clearly and they were obviously enjoying themselves. Unfortunately I had no camera with me...
by Julie Barnes:  I saw tracks and a slide!

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Hidden Lakes Park, Martinez.  Feb. 2, 2013
properties.Notes: by Mary Anne Fakharzadeh:  Otter head was seen on far side of water/lake, otter submerged and was observed breathing under water as I followed it's air bubbles along the edge of the lake until the otter poked it's head out. The otter stared at me for a few moments and then dove in and out of the water a couple of times before submerging again. I could not see it again.

properties.Description: 2 River Otters, Tennessee Valley Lagoon.  4 Feb 2013
properties.Notes: by Peter Kruse: The two otters were eating, staying very close to each other. Seemed to be foraging. Occasionally watched us, watching them. They stayed around the cat-tails(?), and swam around about a 20 yard area before disappearing about 5 minutes after we started watching them.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter - Chimney Rock, Point Reyes Nat'l. Seashore.  Feb. 5, 2013
properties.Notes: by Marcia Johnson:  We observed the otter from the bluff near the garage, standing on the straw near the controls of the sewer system. The otter was down the hill in the water, to the right of the first boat dock. He was on top of a 6'x6' round steel barrel - on the top, eating what my husband determined was a fish.

properties.Description: 1 River Otter, Salmon Creek Marsh.  7 February, 2013
properties.Notes: by Brooke O'Connor
by Matt Kohn:
by Dave Barry: All 4 were swimming and climbing out of the water onto a floating solar panel. 1 was eating it captured 2 trout. 2 were preening each other.
by Robert Rust:  Swimming upstream on the flood tide about one hour before the high peak.

by Julie Barnes: I saw a single otter on land! He saw me seeing him, then humped his body not unlike a defecating dog and did a little hiney shake. He then rubbed his body on the ground and rolled a bit in about a five foot length of a visible worn path.
He then slipped into the water and became invisible.

I caught up with him as I headed back along the path to go home and saw him run across the very shallow cemented creekbed under the bridge.

properties.Notes: The otter was seen on shore moving around in brush along the southwest bank (opposite shoreline of the facilities and paved trail at the lake).  If you were to come down the inlet stream and stay on the west side of the stream as you head around the lake, there is a section that the trail hugs the hillside. There are bushes, trees, and reeds creating a remote area along the lake side for about a 200 foot section or longer.  This is the area the otter was seen.  I saw it two different times, but briefly as it moved through the bushes.  It was distinguishable by its tail and fur, and weasel shaped body.  I have seen many river otters on shore, and am certain this was an otter.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Rodeo Lagoon, Marin Headlands. March 11, 2014.

properties.Notes: I'm a police detective, and was first on scene of a reported suicide.  The victim jumped of the north west piling of the railroad trestle just west of the E Street. bridge where Hwy 70 enters Marysville, CA.  I used my Steiner marine binoculars to search the river for the victim.  I saw no sign of the victim, but saw the otter at least seven times.  He/she was just west of the trestle in the area we were searching.  He was diving into the river and coming up and lying on his/her back to eat objects gathered from the river.I'm an experienced scuba diver and have met the sea otter that lives off the point in Monterey where the El Torito restaurant sits.  He's visited me several times, and he's not the warm a cuddly sweat heart everyone thinks he is.  I'm usually at Macafee assisting my instructor.  The Macafee otter loves to empty the spare weights and masks out of our float and chew holes in the float.  I know an otter when I see one.  They only good thing about that day was the otter.  The person we were looking for jumped int the river and as recovered deceased.The otter was real, and a joy on top of a pretty crappy day.  I see a lot of death. I know an otter when I see one and I'm joyous that there is a resident otter under the rail road trestle west of the E street Bridge in. Marysville.

properties.Notes: I saw this otter's wake from the pedestrian bridge and waited for him to come out.  He made several swimming passes with a side to side flip turn, then climbed to the grassy part of the bank.He sprayed twice while looking straight at me, then went back in the water and swam under the highway bridge and toward the marsh.On the same short walk, I also observed  four beavers and a muskrat.

properties.Notes: Behavior: Swimming downstream, would dive under and come up again, sometimes rolling over in the water.  When it came up, it appeared to be crunching on something (maybe crayfish but we were not close enough to see).Hinebaugh Creek is a heavily altered urban stream channel in an urban area in the City of Rohnert Park!We did try to take photos but the picture is too small and indistinct to show the otter clearly, even though we got quite a good view of its head and tail for ID.
Irrigation Canal in Fresno - took picture on my iphone
2 young otters (1/2 adult size), rolling in the water of the lagoon.  1 Baby who was climbing in a tree & splashing in water near pond.

We went out on the wooden pier that extended into the water.  We heard movement underneath the pier.  A few seconds later the otters came up for air several yards from the pier.  We left and continued our walk and the otters seem to follow - popping up to look at us.  Then as we walked toward the reeds at one end, they headed in the same direction.  See photos.  Wish I had a telephoto lens :) Also couldn't tell if they were adults or pups - they seemed small for adult otters, but don't know if different species vary in size.

I plan on haunting the place until I get a decent photo.

They swam back & forth, popping their heads up like jack-in-a-box, I could not be sure what they were eating, but the egrets nearby were eating a lot of frogs.I have a video on my phone, but may need help up loading as I'm tech challenged.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Los Gatos Creek County Park. June 4, 2014.
properties.Notes: percolation pond
Near the dam and the water outlet in Lake Lagunitas

In front of our house at southernmost end of Sausalito, sighted on the outcropping of a large rocks in the Sausalito section of San Francisco Bay waters, within about 100 feet from a tidal sandy beach shore.
This is the second sighting of otters on the rock piles in front of our home. The first was a few months ago, and there was more than one then.

Our six year old grandson saw the latest one and was quite excited. We got our binoculars, and yes, three adults are absolutely sure it was an otter. I called Wildcare, and the Marine Mammal Center to report it.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Lake Temescal Regional Park. June 22, 2014.
properties.Notes: We posted a camera at a latrine site, where otters might enter and exit the water. On 6/18/14 we got one otter on camera. On 6/22/14 we got multiple pictures of 2 otters exiting the water and moving about on the trail that circles the lake.
Adults were quite large as I was surprised how big they were. I was on an 8 mile run and surprised them as they ran for the delta.

on our deck eating our Koi from our pond.. When they saw us they jumped in the top of our waterfall, went down the waterfall, swam across our pond, jumped out and ran across our garden out into a ditch in the front of our house.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Coyote Hills Regional Park. June 29, 2014.
properties.Notes: Observed along the trail near the island in the channel. Otter was first spotted along the trail and then observed around the island. Otter was swimming swiftly and surfacing. Otter hopped out on land once. Many large carp in the rapidly drying channel may have been the otter's target.
The otter never came ashore during the 30 or so minutes we observed it foraging and feeding. It would surface long enough to consume its kill.
Only saw the large otter heading for the pond.
Possibly 7 otters.
The otter was eating something- making lots of noise while chewing. Lots of white whiskers.
Pristine mountain stream in southern oregon. Do river otters sometimes gnaw on small pieces of tree? Found some gnaw marks, but not from a beaver in the same area where we spotted the otter

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Coyote Hills Regional Park, July 8, 2014
properties.Notes: Otters were seen in the D.U.S.T. marsh swimming towards their presumed home - bank under overhanging brush - where they disappeared - west side.
Hit by car
The otters were swimming upstream late evening along a bank lined with tule reeds.
Redwood Creek in Muir Woods, observed from Main Trail near Bridge 2

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Coyote Hills Regional Park, July 17, 2014
properties.Notes: We saw it it swim across the marsh channel and into it's nest. It's right below the branches....it had fur, shiny from the water and was kinda slender/longish. I want to say beaver but apparently they've never been around here. I sent some pictures to the Naturalist Francis Mendoza at Coyote Hills and he also though it was an otter. The nest was near the trail, underneath a tree.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Pt Reyes National Seashore, July 17, 2014
properties.Notes: point reyes natl seashore, farm pond across sir francis drake from G ranch main driveway
Canal trail by Gregory in pleasant hill california
Shallow arm of lake. In & out of water (on bank). Feeding - couldn't tell what they were eating.

properties.Description: 3 Otters - Las Gallinas Sanitation Ponds, July 19, 2014
properties.Notes: The water was really low at Las Gallinas, and we could see the otters going into and out of several exposed burrows that we had never seen before. The burrows were on one of the islands. We were watching from the trail between ponds one and two near the northernmost defunct dock, looking back at the island.
Two golf courses among vineyards with streams and ponds throughout. There are also turkeys, geese, ducks, egrets, heron, squirrels, hares, frogs, eagles,
460 Canal St, San Rafael, CA from my balcony over the canal.
Moving through marina

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Kent Lake Pump House, July 26, 2014
properties.Notes: Kent Lake near the pump house, Marin County, CA
Very shallow (8inches Creek stream)
Creek next to Pleasant Hill Intermediate School
They were playing in the water, swimming, then they went on the land, rolled arounds, played, entered the water again and swam into the cattails.

Seadrift Lagoon. I saw the first one between the deck and floating dock of my neighbor at 63 Dipsea Road. Then I saw the pair off the dock of my home at 61 Dipsea Road. This is the first time I've seen them since spring. There was also a lot of scat on the docks of both houses. Unfortunately, I washed my deck clean before reading that you want to collect it. There is still scat on the 63 Dipsea dock. You are welcome to come onto my property any time to collect scat.

They were coming/going from under the deck (where they are not visible and are very protected) and then swimming under the floating dock (where they can see what is going on around them but are somewhat hidden and protected). I could only see their bodies when they leapt up to go under the deck. Based on size, at least two of them appear to be young adults -- neither large nor small. The third one is the same size or possibly larger.

I know from last year that my floating dock is a resting, sleeping spot the otters like and use frequently. They swim beneath the floating dock and sleep in the gap between the pontoons and the decking. They also use the land-based deck at 59 Dipsea very frequently. That property has a deck constructed in such a way that there is a gap between the bulk head and the deck. The otters swim up to the bulk head and then climb through the gap to the space under the deck. Last summer both the single male and the mother with two pups would go there.

At 6:50 pm I saw two (possibly three) drop into the Seadrift Lagoon, coming out from under the deck at 63 Dipsea Road (next to my property at 61 Dipsea Road). They swam under the floating dock at 63 Dipsea briefly. Then they swam into the lagoon. I watched one eat a fish.

A quarter mile up from C@H going towards Martinez. Had seen dolphin in the area a few days ago. Was there at morning high tide to see if the dolphin were still around. Was pleasantly surprised to see the otters.
Estuary, the tidally influenced end of Americano Creek is called Estero Americano, near Valley Ford.
I saw four otters were scurrying around the rocks in Sonoma Creek below my property. They moved downstream into a long deep pool.
Bon Tempe dam. on the dam. playing and eating something, and think it was a fish/trout
Mendocino County, CA Big River - approximately 1 mile from mouth of river
Near mouth of Estero de Limantour, swimming along shoreline.
We found numerous scat sites around the lakeshore with crushed up crayfish shells in them. The scats were in various stages of decomposition indicating extended period of habitation by the otters.

properties.Description: 3 Otters - Bucks Lake, Plumas County, August 6, 2014
properties.Notes: We found numerous scat sites around the lakeshore with crushed up crayfish shells in them. The scats were in various stages of decomposition indicating extended period of habitation by the otters.
Mother and two pups foraging, and a singleton foraging about 100 m south of the group.
Otter has broken back legs. James Doc Hale trying to live trap it. Thinks it was due to car or conibear trap.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Vasona Lake Los Gatos, August 10, 2014
properties.Notes: I came upon the otter while kayaking
Marin County; Bon Tempe lake near the exit pipes at Lagunitas end of the lake (near Lagunitas parking area)
Swimming/feeding in man-made Seadrift Lagoon

properties.Description: 5 Otters - Spinnaker Point Lagood, San Rafael, August 18, 2014
properties.Notes: Private lagoon for housing developments surrounding the lagoon. Lagoon is approximately 1/8th of a mile from San Rafael Bay. There are drainage pipes which empty into the lagoon.
Slough
I could only really see their heads and they were in constant motion,  but it seemed that one or maybe two of the otters were the focus of the most attention, as if they were the adults.
Excited to see new wildlife in the newly restored wetlands!
One adult and three pups

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Eden Landing Ecological Reserve, August 26, 2014
properties.Notes: Salt pond habitat at the southern portion of Eden Landing Ecological Reserve, pond E3c. The otters started swimming SE after they were by the tree stump(as seen in pictures) and would go in and out of pickle weed by the salt pond shore.

Seemed to be exploring/moving through the area. Went back a few hours later and did not see them, though there was a big turtle. Didn't even know the creek had water in it right now let alone multiple forms of wildlife!
Crossing levee rd. Above a small beach bounded by Willow and bamboo. The juvenile was in the center of the road and the adult was on the side of the road with head crushed.

The otter was swimming west to east at approximately the mid-point of the north shore of the park. It was actively diving and searching underwater as it made its way along the shore. There is extensive underwater algae at this location and the otter may have been foraging for small fish or invertebrates. I did not see it come up with any prey items.
Boat docks in lagoon. They come up to eat clams, mussels, small crabs.
The lake is lined with grasses, reeds, cattails and such; I did not see any tracks, etc.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Island Lake, Tahoe National Forest, September 1, 2014
properties.Notes: It came very close to me and stuck its head out of the water. Then it swam in an undulating motion like dolphins do, and breached the water many times as it swam. It also got up on a rock and either ate something or groomed itself; at this point it was too far away for me to see whether eating or grooming. It walked across the rock, dove in on the other side, and swam away. I watched it in the distance repeating the breaching behavior.
In Corte Medera Creek main channel near Niven Park mudflats. The otter was surfacing and diving so my observation allowed me to see the entire body.

Our lot borders the former Larkspur Creek (what's left of it after it was diverted long ago to flow under Doherty Drive and out to Corte Madera Creek). Now the "creek" is little more than a drainage ditch into which the run off from the Redwood High School football field pours. But our lot is at the end of the street and there is a small "pond" at the termination of the "creek".

Location was a creek that has public walking paths on both sides, also a bridge to cross. Very close to college campus, donkey and/or horses nearby in stables. I followed them down the creek for a bit (going southwest) until I got distracted by some birds.

Bon Tempe Lake on the Pine Point Trail looking towards the dam. They swam from the shore about 20 feet out and began eating and vocalizing. We watched them for 10 minutes or so and then they swam further out into the lake.

Over the course of 3 or 4 minutes, I observed 2 individuals swimming/diving from one end of Phoenix Lake dam to the other. One appeared to be a bit larger and seemed to have more whiskers; I think I may have seen a male/female pair.
