properties.Description: 1 Otter - Oak Hill Park, Danville, September 9, 2014
properties.Notes: Though I've not seen otters here before, one of the Town of Danville employees mentioned that they've be coming for the last few years--even pups this past spring. Apparently they come through the drainage system from the local creeks.
Everyone looked happy and healthy heading out towards the bay!
Otters were swimming close to the North Shore.  They looked at me for a while and disappeared. I searched for about 10 minutes, but never saw them again.

In what should be ponds (almost none now because of the drought) and Novato creek area on the north side of highway 37. It is an area where people walk their dogs and some people just walk and enjoy the scenery. Coyotes, geese, white pelicans and many ducks and shore birds also in the same area.

Hearing the otter's grumblings brought my awareness to attention at once.  Following his grass foraging and ending with his swim out on the Lake once again reminded me of how uplifting observations in Nature can be.
Just a creek with lots of debris, garbage, water plants, and visible fish swimming. It was near a busy bridge.
Lake Lagunitas near the junction of the new boom and what's left of the old, log boom near the dam.  One of them got up onto the old boom very briefly. The were headed east.
We were sitting stream side when the otter swam downstream right where we were sitting and then quickly made a sharp turn jutting diagonally downstream.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Oak Hill Park, Danville, September 18, 2014
properties.Notes: Scat found three days later, on high rock along edge of pond. Appeared to be filled with crayfish shell bits and pieces.
Otter were in the water, foraging along the shore, one caught a fish and brought it halfway out of the water and ate it.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Hole in the Head, Bodega Bay, September 19, 2014

properties.Notes: The individuals ran out across beach from adjacent shrubs and into the water. Tracks were later found traversing that section of beach.

It was feeding on sthg. CRUNCHY; I was standing at top of bank, admiring new wood duck boxes on the n. side of the creek, when I heard the crunching perhaps amplified by the water but otter was out of water except for feet -- I saw body, tail, and legs; -- but could not see head or what it was eating: I saw tracks of its webbed feet just back of it

We have seen an otter or two over the past 25 years, but in the last two years we have had a family of 4 otters consistently play on our kayak and dock. They climb up on our swim ladder or jetski dock and use our carpet to roll around and scratch. They groom each other and sun on the dock.
Playing, swimming in the lagoon
Muir Beach front lagoon and woods seen from the footbridge.
Papermill Creek at White House Pool - from the parking lot, I walked to the trail, turned right, saw them just a little ways down.

Spotted 7 otters swimming in Briones Reservoir while on a morning run. There could have been a couple of more otters but 7 was the most we saw above water at the same time. Trail was approximately 30 feet in elevation above where the otters were swimming, so it provided a great view to observe them as they swam along the shoreline.

I never saw them feeding while in the water. They lifted their nose/heads skyward - with mouth open and jaws working methodically. Both adults and then the pup?! Hung around the spot for a minute or two - then moved westward in the creek.

properties.Description: 1 Otter -- Corte Madera Creek, Larkspur, September 28, 2014
properties.Notes: Swimming just under surface and popped his/her head up for just a moment. Otter was about 10 feet from my kayak.
swimming close together 30 feet in front of deck, heading out to the central Bay
Swimming in river and came to shore eating fish. Saw me and took off swimming from bridge to marina area (east).
Saw them swimming between dam and first bridge on the right, then saw them between 2nd and 3rd bridge coming out of water to a hard to see latrine area.
Behind the abandoned park buildings.  A fresh scat was found as well.
Drakes Estero, 1/4 mile S of kayak put in

We were unable to see any such otter made landmarks due to lower light condition. They swam and rolled together for several minutes, then got out of the water onto the bank, where both sat and alertly watched us. We walked around the whole pond and they were no longer in the same spot when we got back.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Hiddenbrooke Golf Club, American Canyon, October 9, 2014
properties.Notes: Hiddenbrooke Golf Course American Canyon in pond between 16th green and 17th tee.
The otters were in the creek, didn't see any sign of tracks.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Willow Pass Park, Concord, December 25, 2013
properties.Notes: I remember the date well because it seemed like the perfect Christmas present!

properties.Description: 5 Otters - Russian River, Duncan Mills, January 2014
1 Otter - Stony Creek, Mendocino National Forest, June 1, 2014
properties.Notes: The Otter was first seen moving on land and water up stream and then seen moving down stream.
Two pups on a rock.
Observed (wildlife camera) on levee top trail approximately 1/4 of mile away from Visitor Center.
On a rock eating a fish. Tracks on the beach.

Lots of splashing and moving as a compact group in a restricted water way . We were in two kayaks trying to find our way in a narrow, about 10 ft. wide, water way across Kimbal island. Though we were within 15 - 20 feet of them they didn't display any fear but just moved across our path and proceeded into the tulles. When we saw them we stopped and did not approach any closer until they cleared the area.
Drake's Estero, west side of Estero near mouth, in cliffs.

Location was a creek that has public walking paths on both sides, also a bridge to cross. Very close to college campus, donkey and/or horses nearby in stables. I followed them down the creek for a bit (going southwest) until I got distracted by some birds.
Swam past the Jenner boat ramp as we were launching our kayaks on the Russian River.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Spring Lake Regional Park, Santa Rosa, September 15, 2014

properties.Notes: Tulocay Creek beaver pond, 75 Yards from Soscol Ave in Napa, next door to the Hawthorn Inn
The river otter was seen in the creek near the bridge and appeared to be a young adult with a salmon head in his mouth!
Corte madera creek, Corte Madera, Marin County, CA 94925 cross lakeside ave. next to and behind Neil Cummins School.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Mad River hatchery, Humboldt, October 10, 2014
properties.Notes: Latrine site on several sandy river beach areas observed all summer long., My dog and I finally walked up on an adult and pup hanging out on our favorite beach. I have been observing 1 or 2 otters all summer across the river from the same beach. The scat is full of crayfish shell pieces, and probably fish scales also, very strong smelling.  I have also seen many otters 10 + hunting near the mouth of the Mad River in Humboldt County in the winter months.
In the Corte Madera high channel which is parallel to Birch Avenue. They were in the channel between Lakeside Drive and the paved bike path (Sandra Marker Path).

properties.Description: 3 Otters - UC Davis Riparian Reserve, October 16, 2014

properties.Notes: In big lake part of arboretum in Davis, CA near Garrod Drive and Equestrian Center

Russian River at Jenner, a couple hundred yards west of the public boat launch and visitor center. This otter was resting on a floating dock. This otter seemed dull-eyed, ungroomed and let me get way too close.

In the Marin Headlands, at the Lagoon. we were on the Miwok trail, heading west, returning to the parking lot, and went on a game trail to the south, which looked out on the part of the lagoon that's east of the little overpass/bridge. so NOT the side that opens into the ocean. We saw what we thought were ducks in the reeds across the lagoon. we used our binoculars and saw they were mammals moving around and pushing some things around. one seemed to have a white strip, or something they were pushing did???? it was dusk and foggy, so hard to see. Then we saw the adult come toward them from the west. they came to the adult, then the adult went into the reeds. we could totally see it was an otter even with the naked eye, and fully with binoculars. the babies weren't ever that clear. then it got too dark and we left. :)
Two otters by Between bridge 1 and 2 medium in size
The otters swam into a dead tree trunk that was hollowed out near the bank. Possibly a den???

Saw bubbles in the north side of the lagoon , and heard some noise. Then saw the otter swimming across to the south side. I watched it swim across the lagoon but lost track of it at the edge and didn't see it get out of the lagoon .
chasing ducks, egret, somewhat aggressive looked like eating floating plants

The otter was not visible until it moved to dive into the bay. It was on rocks very close to the shore. The surface is hard, cratered, and one would not expect tracks. There is little or no land vegetation on the tidal region, except seaweed on the portions usually submerged, and sea pickle and other salt-tolerant species on portions mostly unsubmerged. There is a lot of volunteer plant population on the plateau above.
Near Hog island on Western side of Tomales Bay.

The location is across the street from the Lagunitas Post Office. There is a small waterfall which spills into a pool. This time I only saw one otter. Usually there are three or four. They like to climb out of the water at the area below the road, adjacent to the waterfall. They also like to hang out on the old log at the waters edge.
A young otter was spotted today by bridge 1 about 4:00 pm. It was just going through the water looking for food.
On our dock.
Another river otter sighting, around Bridge 1, at 2:45
We were walking on land separating the ponds. There is a tunnel or otter crossing that crosses this area from pond to pond.
There was another otter sighting between Bridge 2 and Bridge 1 around 10:00 in the morning
500 yards west of Bon Tempe Dam in Alpine Lake. Playing along the north bank.
We watched them swim under the bridge near the pond. They swam close to the bottom and made a trail of sediment in the water.

Seen through a window at the Tides Restaurant at Bodega Bay. Swimming quite near shore. The otter swam from under an apparently abandoned building on pilings, north of the restaurant and swam south to underneath the restaurant (also on pilings). About 10 minutes later it made a return trip
Lake Lagunitas, east end of lake.
Saw otter coming from the ocean at Drakes Beach in Pt. Reyes; it scampered across the beach and into a small pond on the western edge of the beach, quite close to the main parking lot.
My boat that I lived on is no longer at the Richmond Yacht club, but otters are still scatting the identical G-Dock seawall at the Club.
Bon Tempe lake, southeast end, at the valve station canal, visible from the walking trail. Near to Lake Lagunitas.

4 otters at shallow beach at 4pm today.  2 young with female that had caught a fish followed by a lone male? Larger and keeping distance but following.  Eating mussels then towards pebble beach. We were alerted because a flock ducks feeding in cove took off in a panic!
Swimming and diving below water surface - appeared to be diving in water for food. Land along side of Santa Rosa was muddy and brush covered so not able to see if there were tracks, slide etc..
Dead, old carcass partially hairless, right hind leg broken possibly predated, bone sticking out.
Point Isabel, in bay near the main parking lot.

Small stream , otter was beside overhanging trees next to a pedestrian bridge.  There are often herons feeding in the creek so I knew there must be fish there. Walk here very day with my dog and this is the most exciting thing I have ever seen. I have always wanted to see a river otter in the wild!
The two were swimming together, diving under the surface, appeared to be looking for food.  They seemed to be playful together, in relation together.

We watched the otters in the small pond for just over 1.5 hours. They stayed as a group in the pond and on the shore. A few times 3 of them separated from the main group and went over a small berm to a smaller adjacent pond (which is now part of the larger pond, since the rains have come). After a while, they all climbed out of the pond and ran across the trail and slipped back into the Bay.

When I saw the otter it was in a large creek pool at the north end of Fryer Creek (Newcomb Street), swimming, rolling, going under water at times. It was quite large. When I came back with my camera the otter traveled south down Fryer Creek according to other observers. I missed my photo opportunity.

This is the first time I have ever seen river otters and I was completely fascinated by them. Adorable. When I stopped to watch them, one got out, climbed on a rock and stared at me. He was making some sort of noise, just talking. Then he jumped back in and joined his friends to wherever they were going.
Reporting party lives in area but has not seen otters or sign in Pine Gulch Creek before.

Swimming and diving in Bel Marin Keys, by our boat dock. The 2 adults would spend some time on their backs at the surface. They were diving for something, but I could not tell what it was. The pups came up and just showed their heads. Then swam off heading north along the shore.
Saw one of the otters bound (leap from point to point as if running) on the creek bank.
We are wondering how it got to Shadow Cliffs, especially with the drought.

The vegetation on the edge of the lake is clearly disturbed on many sides of lake. Did not see any scat or a latrine site, but possible corridors around the edge of the lake. It is hard to tell with so many people and dogs walking around the lake.
Fryer creek. We observed several 4 to 6 in late 2012 early 2013, but this is the first one I have seen since then.

properties.Description: 6 Otters - Russian River, Duncan Mills, November 30, 2014
properties.Notes: Six small otters were swimming upriver (east) on near the south bank of the Russian River. I saw them as they approached the bridge in Duncans Mills near the intersection of Freezeout & Moscow roads.

They were sighted in a small creek in an area with lots of reeds and vegetation. They were swimming in a deeper pool of water under the bridge. They may have been foraging. The otters seemed to be enjoying the moving deeper water after the heavy rains.
The poor adult Otter, was found on the street side on Wildcat Blvd next to Margaret Azevedo Park. I believe he climbed up the hill from the wetland strip and unfortunately got hit.

I know what we saw was an otter, but I (probably mistakenly) assumed it was a sea otter, since it was in SF Bay. It was very near the shoreline, as close as 2' to the rip-rap, and it swam and dove intermittently, coming up once with a fish in its mouth. About 10' farther out was a string of bubbles, and an otter appeared there, too. Not at the same moment, so I was unsure as to whether there were two or only one.

I have been observing this otter for a couple of weeks. Today I watched him for over 15 minutes hanging out on the rocks above the creek, rolling on his back and rubbing himself against the smooth rocks. He seemed to be quite content and not at all concerned about the few of us watching him. He appears to be maybe 25 lbs or so. Other people have observed 2 otters together recently but I have only seen 1 alone in the last few days.
They were squeezing through a fence and rushing down to the Canal.
They all looked like they were happy to be surfing. All they needed was a Beach Boys soundtrack.
aprox 1/2 mile up Tulocay Creek from the Napa River in a Beaver Dam. There is a Beaver lodge next to where I saw the two otters.

In Novato on Fairway Drive near Birdie Drive. Saw it cross in front of me towards where the stream that goes thru Marin Country Club goes under the road. It was long (about 2 feet long) and kind of waddled / ran quickly across the road into the bushes near the water. I couldn't help but notice its long, thick, tapered tail.
It was in the water, diving over and over and coming up making crunching noise and I saw one crayfish in its mouth but otherwise just heard crunching
Montezuma Slough

A year round stream empties into Tomales Bay at the center of Reynolds cove. We have been sighting this family of otters for many years. The otters appear to live in the stream drainage and come to the bay to forage and hunt.
The otter was heading up-stream on the east side of the creek in the rocky area just above Bridge 1.
By the log jam above Bridge 1 cleaning itself. Then hit the rapids again and was down stream in a flash
Diving along the banks, at one point looking at me on shore and eating something small that I could not discern.

properties.Description: 3 Otters - Hidden Lakes Park, Martinez, December 26, 2014

properties.Notes: We had just begun our hike up Cataract Trail at the East Fork of Alpine Lake when we saw some movement just on the other side of the lake from us. We had binoculars so we were able to see that there were five otters swimming single file. The lake was narrow in that spot (it wasn't far from the creek) so they were close enough for us to get a good look. Both my partner and I saw them so we are quite sure they were otters! They were slowly meandering north not far from the side of the lake. We watched them for about ten minutes until they swam out of our range.
Otter was grooming and sunning on a rock. Taking drinks of water from water runoff flowing into bay.

I regularly see otters near here. Today, there was a single adult otter running on the dock and sniffing the edges of the dock. It then entered the water, swam under the dock and then swam into the nearby reeds. There were no tracks on the dock, which I thought was strange. Usually, they leave wet footprints. I saw wet footprints earlier coming from the marina. I saw a heel in one, which I don't usually see, which is why I was looking online and saw your website. It would be easy to find scat here.

Point Isabel Dog Park and Regional Shoreline, Albany. Otter sunned itself on rocks near the walking trail just west of the parking lot by the cafe, then dove in water and swam southward, scaring off a flock of birds.
We saw the otter swimming across the lake and diving occasionally under the water.
All four ran down to the beach from the higher marshland. they loped across the beach and into the waves. they swam out and headed north beyond our line of sight. They all seemed healthy and playful.

Spotted by 3 kids (about 7-11) who were very excited, as was I when I saw the otters also! They said they had seen a single otter earlier, but it was not clear to me that it was not from this same family. The three were foraging in a very tight group, and climbed up bank for a couple of minutes out of sight, then back in creek and continued foraging in an upstream direction. This is presumably the same family group which has been in the creek on and off since last summer.

properties.Description: 5 Otters - Hidden Lakes Park, Martinez, January 1, 2015
properties.Notes: I just found you folks. I have been photographing the river otters in and around Hidden Lakes Park in Martinez , Ca. For the past three years. Hope you can use the photos and information. The otters have been spending their winter months in the lake feasting on catfish, trout, crawdads and so much more. I have observed up to six otters in one sighting.
Otter was swimming on the surface from out in the lake into the deep cove with Redwood trees at the back where he submerged and disappeared.
Grizzly Slough on Grizzly Island Road.
Bon Tempe Lake, Marin County, in a bay on the northeastern corner of the lake.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Lagoon Valley Park, Vacavill, January 3, 2015
properties.Notes: Talking to a photographer who was there, he said there was 6 and they've been for a couple of weeks. There used to be turtle in the pond. But I think the drought killed them not the otters.
Wooded area around the lake. Near the dam.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Spring Lake Regional Park, Santa Rosa, January 5, 2015
properties.Notes: On path above the creek bed running through Spring Lake Regional Park, Santa Rosa. Adult (assume it was the mother) was leading 3 pups (about 70% adult size, I'd guess) down the path; they headed into under brush by the creek bed when they saw me.

I'm pretty sure that 2 were pups but they could have been small females. They were right by the shore, about 10 feet away. By the time I realized what they were and tried to take a picture, they ducked under the water and swam away.
Golf course, man-made lake. Only natural water nearby is a creek that runs parallel to the golf course.
At the Bridge Street Bridge. Was foraging downstream of the bridge but then went upstream and out of view.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Ellis Lake Park, Concord, January 9, 2015
properties.Notes: This is the second time I've seen an otter here. I talked to someone who lives nearby and she says she often sees it at 6AM in one particular area. I didn't expect to just see one otter by itself but she has never seen more than one either.
At the end of Harbor Point Road in Strawberry, Mill Valley
Giacomini Wetlands/Mouth of Papermill Creek

Otters spotted at 7:30am swimming/foraging in lower lagoon. They then went out of sight (presumably stayed in lower lagoon) until 9:30 when they crossed under bridge to upper lagoon and came out onto sandbank for some minutes to roll/slide/play/urinate in the sand.
Otter rested on the black pipe running parallel to the dam between swims for fish. Later it rested on the left of 2 logs in a cove just beyond the Orange floaters on rope.
North end of Nicasio Reservoir, swimming towards shore. Water was flat with no wind, and could see it had been swimming at the surface for some distance.

Spotted a group of 3 near the bank South East from where I was standing.  There was some splashing and vocalizing as they were exploring near the bank, then a fish (trout) darted under my rod and line and one otter followed behind it. Another followed parallel a little farther from shore. The third stayed farther back. This one I think was a pup, it looked a little bit smaller.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Ellis Lake Park, Concord, January 15, 2015
properties.Notes: People in the area tell me they have seen 4 otters at a time. I think I know where they may live, the park is full of people, including homeless and others, and the park is small, only a city block, but there is a pipe that maybe leads across the street to another water area. There is a lot of wildlife in this tiny park, egrets and 2 kinds of herons, plus ducks, geese, turtles, etc.
Lagunitas Creek in Inverness Park at Balboa.
Sitting on the bank of a slough then jumping into said slough and swimming.

properties.Description: 6 Otters - Lower Putah Creek, Winters,  January 19, 2015
properties.Notes: 1 group of 4 diving. 2 singles. spotted them down the creek on logs playing.

I am concerned about the otter's well-being. S/he was by itself and I spotted it multiple times. It was doing a good job of swimming just outside of the low tide area. Some were concerned that it may get to close to the dogs and get injured by the dogs, though I'm pretty sure it could out manuver a dog. I didn't see it eating or hunting. I haven't seen it this week, so I hope it is ok.
In SGV stream behind house.
Lots of vegetation on banks, otters were in the middle diving and when they noticed me looking from the bridge retreated to the banks.
The otter was sleeping and working on a tan. As you can tell by the photo, otters are a regular visitor to my dock..

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Blucher Creek, Sonoma County, January 25, 2015
properties.Notes: Blucher Creek about 100 meters west of Azalea Lane, in unincorporated Sonoma County about 4 miles southeast of Sebastopol, caught on wildlife camera during daytime.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Ellis Lake Park, Concord, January 28, 2015
properties.Notes: My neighbor pointed out the otter as I was walking home through the park. She told me that she has counted three in total, and has been seeing them for the last several days.

Approximately 11:45 AM on January 28, 2015 I saw a river otter on the south shore of the Albany Bulb - a landfill in San Francisco Bay composed primarily of construction debris and concrete rubble. The otter was swimming in the water and seemed like it was attempting to come to shore. However, two people were nearby with their dog (offleash) and the dog was interested in the otter. The otter would approach land, get disturbed by the dog, and then would go underwater and would resurface a little further down the shore. The otter was around for approximately 3-5 minutes, and then it went further offshore, and then I lost track of it.
They are in a creek behind our house. We have been watching them for about 3-4 months. Pretty cool, we walk the canal trail everyday and see them about 25% of the time.
It was up by bridge 3 in Redwood Creek, Muir Woods heading down stream. No distinguishing behaviors noted.
Habitat: manmade tertiary water treatment pond.  Otter flushed Cinnamon teal from cattails and caused the Marsh Wrens to scold vigorously.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Contra Loma Lake, Antioch, February 2, 2015

properties.Notes: Half way down E side Bon Tempe Lake, Marin County, near where vehicle access road is closest to the lake shore
There is a stream area in the wetlands, was located in an area that was clear of cat-tails.
In Sonoma Developmental Center next to large bridge on Harney Rd

Lafayette Reservoir: East side across from pier 3. River otters were all playing on the land across from the pier. I see them many times throughout the year while fishing. You can tell where the otters are swimming because the birds in the area fly away when the otters are present.  I have seen mom, dad and 2 pups. The parents are big 3-4 ft long.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Hidden Lake Park, Martinez, February 1, 2015
properties.Notes: These otter have been amazing to watch these past few months. I have seen them slide, roll, mark, eat, swim, hassle the cormorants, run on land, vocalize, found scat, and play. What a treat they are.

They fed, right below the water fall coming from above from Lake Lagunitas then disappeared under the flue structure that carried the water from Lake Lagunitas down to the stream that went to Bon Tempe

It is very close to the hiking trail (the otter certainly noticed us) and it does not appear that there was a clear entrance point (slide). The bank was stoney, but there could have been a slide where the water was still running into the lake. There are still puddles along the trail and fresh mud in places. We know cat, dog and coyote tracks... there were tracks that were none of those out there... but we can't say for sure that they were otter.
No tracks. It was looking for, and found, a way to get through the fence and back down to the creek.

I see river otters at Phoenix often, but this guy was so big and healthy, and having the nicest time swimming and diving that I had to write it up. I wonder if it's appreciated that the otters have found the lake, but it was great to see him/her none-the-less.
They seemed more weary than usual. There may have been more than two but I never saw more than two at one time. The tide was low, difficult to see through the cat tails.

We see an otter in Shelter Bay (a small part of the estuary) from time to time every other month. It swims along the edges, coming up for air then swimming under water, but we don't see it do much else.
3 otters crossed Lagoon Road and went into the lagoon, which you can see from Lagoon Road. I think there is a tunnel under Point San Pedro Road right there, near the water plant.

properties.Description: 3 Otters - San Ramon Creek, Alamo, March 1, 2015
properties.Notes: One climbed out of stream onto a log in the creek while other two were close, remaining in water. Stayed on log for about 30 seconds, then into water. Swam off, all three submerged. Observed from 50 or so feet away atop of bank.
Definitely feeding, not sure on what. One time the sound of the crunch made me think crayfish. Other times probably fish.
There was a dry creek bed running along the road. I saw the otter cross Harrison Grade rd and go down into the creek bed. It went up into the culvert under a driveway.

I saw one otter in the creek that runs along the Iron Horse Train in San Ramon, between Montevideo and Pine Valley Roads (behind the high school). I walk this route nearly every day M-F and have not seen otters previously. But I will be keeping a lookout for one or more in the future so will keep you posted. The otter appeared to enter a den in the bank of the creek.

Three seemingly full grown otters swimming together under the Hwy 86 bridge through Lake Solano County Park. Lake Solano is an impoundment of Putah Creek near Winters, CA. The three were headed east. This is about 200 meters south of Hwy 128.

The otters foraged and appeared to feed from the shallow bottom of the lagoon. They would dive for 2-3 seconds, resurface, face toward me, and chew :). Their chewing sounds were audible. The moved west diving and feeding along the north bank of the lagoon.

The otter was seen swimming, fishing and eating by several members of our hiking group. We observed the otter through binoculars. Wendy Dreskin, the naturalist leading the hike, thought that the otter was probably eating a crayfish rather than a fish (e.g., trout) given the time it took it to eat the critter.

River otter was observed swimming in the ocean. One individual appeared to be swimming from a small drainage between the elephant seal overlook and the colony at Drake's Bay. The otter was first observed in the water approx. 50 feet offshore, so not 100% clear that it was coming from land, but seems very likely. Prior to confirming it was an otter, I had glimpsed something diving a few feet from the drainage outlet, which I had initially assumed was a waterbird but was probably the otter. During the course of the observation, I observed the otter swimming in a straight line northeast across Drake's Bay, swimming on the surface briefly between short dives. The otter was assumed to be an adult since it was alone.
Los Gatos Creek widens just before the dam. The sides of the pool of water are primarily concrete. The animal was near the only grassy bank.
Swimming upstream on Lagunitas Creek at low tide.
The otter was close to where the lagoon breaches into the ocean. It was on the sand and rolling around until it decided to go back to swimming in the lagoon.
4 heads popped up out of the water
Swimming in slough. Many chirping vocalizations (which makes me think it was a mother with young).
In a slough. It was curious and allowed me in a kayak to glide up rather close.  This was the first time we've seen an otter in this slough.
There were 2 otters in the water swimming and playing and one other one that kept getting in and out of the water to bask in the sun and groom.
I saw them swimming in our pond from my house above the pond.

It walked out of the water, seemed to forage around a bit and then headed to a debris pile. This is at our home near Lake Berryessa in Napa County. We've been here 10 years and I was excited and shocked to see an otter in our creek!
Otter had been hit by a motor vehicle, was deceased laying in the roadway.
Otter found in Roadway hit by motor vehicle, deceased.
Road kill.
Swam by underwater; surfaced briefly; dove under overhanging tree roots/hollowed creek bank.
Tennessee Beach - saw otter exit the surf and run towards the lagoon above the beach and then (same otter?) return to the beach and enter the surf about 30 minutes later.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, January 12, 2015
properties.Notes: River otters are quite common at the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.

Approximately 8 to 10 otters are killed on this road annually since about 2010. Prior to that year no otters were observed killed on the road from 2000 to 2010. Mink and beaver are also killed on the road by I am able to identify the difference.
Disappeared into small culvert
Creek crossing under morelli lane

We have seen up to three adults swimming/playing in the area of our dock for last three years. The present animal defecates on our dock, directly on top of the lines that tie my boat to the dock. Has been doing this for last five consecutive days. Hard to collect scat because mixed in with rope. I hose it off daily. If there is value in collecting, I would need detailed instructions. Maybe critter will pick a clear area.

Glad a I found your website. Also, did not know what I was seeing. Had to type in small California mammels and look at many pictures before coming to the conclusion that this was a river otter. I may have seen another one way out on dry land. Thought they were related to a fox owing to little protruding ears. Very exciting! will keep my eyes open for more. This area has really become a bird and mammals sanctuary.
This otter was directly under the iron horse trail bridge playing in a deeper part of the creek.

The otter was swimming with the tide coming in (south) and appeared to be checking both sides of the banks out. After swimming and zigzagging in about a 20 foot section for 10 to 15 minutes, it swam toward the center berm and moved into the tall grasses.
The Otter was on its hind legs. He saw us then scampered into the creek
Middle Slough before marker 12 on the trail
Otter was swimming upstream completely submerged. I lost sight of it before it came out of the water.
South Petaluma Drawbridge/Sheraton Marina. We were sitting on the east side of the river.

I saw an adult river otter sleek, quick and scampering from the bracken pond across the beach and into the ocean waves. I saw him dive into the crashing waves. He disappeared for a short time and then reappeared parallel to the beach his head stuck out for a quick, 2 second peek, about 20 feet out, almost to the small rock jutting out near what used to be Arch Rock. I lost him again. Then, a short while later, maybe 15 minutes, I got a real good look at him. He was emerging from the water at the exact point where he went in, and he ran back across the beach running across the sand and back to the pond.
They've been pretty active in this area over the last few weeks although I don't have the proper data to report it thoroughly here.
Marshall Cove, Tomales Bay California
Lake Lagunitas. I overheard someone say they also saw pups but I didn't see them.
Dead. Vultures feeding on carcass.

Observed otters swimming and exiting the river on both the north and south banks. Both sides of the river have heavy foliage. Otters were seen rolling in sandy patches. Fresh scat was found on south bank 10 meters from the shoreline.
Rodeo Lagoon, West side
Dutchman slough, about 1/2 mile from the Napa river in Vallejo. The Entrance to Dutchman slough is very close to the highway 37 bridge across the Napa river.
Russian River in Monte Rio, Ca. on & in water next to island, about 1 mile downriver from Monte Rio bridge.

Barbara on the Pt Reyes Birding & WIldlife Festival walk along Drake's Estero told me about your organization and suggested I send the pictures of this lovely otter dining! He had been eating a crab and then we spied him and he jumped into the water. He began diving and soon returned with a great meal!
Southern shore on the east finger of Lake Lagunitas
Swimming in a farm pond off Buchli Station Road in Napa, just before CDFW Huichica Creek unit parking lot.
Nut Tree Road and Marshall Road in Alamo Creek, Vacaville CA
About 50 yards off the end of First St. in Benicia. Observed from a kayak.
Abbotts Lagoon. The otter swam under the bridge from the western side of the lagoon to the more inland part of the lagoon. Then he swam toward the shoreline on the northern side.

At Rush Ranch we saw an otter along the banks of Suisun Slough while we were walking along the trail. We saw the otter on the way out and on the way back near the big bend in the trail that goes back to Rush Ranch.

I've seen lots of river otters on Tomales Bay, but I'd never seen a river otter at this location. After watching it swim around the harbor in front of the Coast Guard station for a while, we could tell that it was definitely not a sea lion or seal. Then we were absolutely sure it was a river otter, because we saw it climb up on the rip rap and disappeared down a large pipe that leads back towards the former base buildings. I mentioned this on Facebook, and someone else from my kayak club mentioned that he'd seen a river otter there as well recently; it could be the same one.
Bon Tempe Reservoir, Shady side
Tulucay Creek, just up stream of Soscol Road crossing in the vicinity of a beaver dam.
He was in the river and leapt by my boat at the base of the rapids. Came and went pretty quickly.

Only seen swimming. Appeared quite fearless as at one time the otter was following the shoreline, swimming toward us( 3 kayaks) while we remained quite still, but still talking quietly, and it approached us, watched for a moment or two, then swam past quite close.
He was splashing then went back into the storm drain.
I heard splashing as I was walking along and then looked over the bridge to see the three in shallow water moving south into Olema Marsh.

Walking smack dab across the road at Bear Valley Creek at park headquarters!!!  I have had two sightings in a week - curious if they are exploring new habitat south of Giacomini/Papermill Creek. The creek is very low. I have seen them in Abbotts Lagoon and in Papermill Creek - first time south of those areas.
Richardson Bay in Mill Valley, across from the Dog Park
Marin headlands rodeo lagoon , swimming quickly west from around the bunker road overpass
Spotted running across the road on the lower level of the RTC campus near building 36
It was swimming and diving at Briones Reservoir & I saw it with binoculars close by
I saw them with my binoculars
We've been seeing 1-2 river otters multiple times per week with our students out on the trail at NatureBridge!
Dead male river otter, adult, well-fed, no obvious wounds, but predated by vultures, instestine and stomach scattered. Did not bring in for necropsy, but collected tissue/hair sample.
Swimming west to east in the Seadrift Lagoon. Appeared to be adults. Lost sight of them after roughly 200 yards.

Southish end, eastern side of Tomales Bay, low tide. There are many rivulets and berms . We walked down the bank , steep path hard to avoid poison oak, and looked out over the bay. All of a sudden we saw him not 20' away, staring up at us. He was floating on the top of the water , whole body visible, I know this sounds funny but for a split second I thought I was looking at an alligator... Really . Such a wide head and long body... We watched each other for a minute or so until he apparently decided we were harmless and continued fishing. Diving under the water he came up with a fish, swam to a bank to eat. We watched him gracefully dive 4 or 5 times, each time before diving he'd float in our direction giving us an intense stare. After he came up with the second fish he made a little noise before going again to the edge of the water to eat. He eventually swam north and we lost sight of him.
Creek that goes through the park.
The person I was walking with stated her friend had seen otters at this location previously. This was the first sighting for both of us.
They are so adorable and, it turns out, quite clever!
Hit by car, adult female otter with large wound near her tail.

On previous sightings I have observed otters playing but today they were acting threatened by swimming towards me in 2's and 3's, barking/hissing and pulling themselves vertically out of the water to observe my position. then they would retreat to their den again, only to repeat the protective swimming toward me again. I did observe one eating, and could hear it crunching on what I think was a crayfish shell. The pond is landlocked with no fish that I know of in the water. the top of the pond is covered in algae bloom. We do see many migratory birds there throughout the year and it is a riparian habitat built by the local Resource Conservation District.

Lake Sonoma, Sonoma California. Upper North East Arm of Lake Sonoma. It was swimming and also climbed up on a bank and moved along the bank for awhile before going back in the water. I was about 15 ft away in a boat.
Just looked out and saw him swimming by - headed towards the creek. Cool!

No tracks or scat and no vocalizations. He was HUGE... spent about 5 min swimming in our creek pool, walking upstream on rocks, returning to the pool. Finally ambled away upstream. Last otter spotted here was over 2 years ago. Pretty exciting!
The otter got onto our boat when we came in from salmon fishing searching for food. He was not given any food by humans. He was attempting to feed on the live bait at the bait shop.
Spooked it from under a rock while collecting fin clips. It ran unbelievably fast past some of us and hid under a boulder. tracks and scat found at larger waterfall pools.
These otters were spotted by Woodinville School from Seattle!
Otter was continuously diving and resurfacing with something to munch on in it's mouth.
Boat harbor-- He came up on dock, rolled around, played /attacked a boat fender , then jumped back in water.
We have almost daily sightings of an otter at this pond.There is a latrine site. A couple of times we have seen two playing together.
There is a latrine site and favorite log for lounging.
They were playing. There is a known latrine site at the pond.
Daily sightings now and for longer duration. A lot of lounging today.
The otter was observed swimming in the creek. At one point it just stayed stationary and it looked like a log.

Since the otters were fairly close in size the distinction between adults and pups has some uncertainty. This is the first sighting in two years and the first time this far from the lake (further up the canals).
I had heard otters were here but thought it was urban legend!
I'm an avid birdwatcher. This lagoon is rich in shoreline bird habitat. River otters have been spotted in this lagoon in the past (2014).
This is a nicely restored area as of last year. Creek is very low, but some refuges with salmonids.
The otter was swimming, pushing a bundle of reeds before it...it the dove down taking the bindle of reeds with it.....it was a large adult.
Did not check for tracks. Otter was spotted in Fairfax Creek swimming and walking along the shore of the creek. May have gone into storm drain pipe.
Lafayette reservoirs adjacent to fishing dock. Called to each other and swam up to me by the dock. Seemed to look for a bit and then swam off under the dock and into the reeds.

I was crossing the bridge when I spotted what I thought were raccoons on one side of the bridge, heading to Bon Tempe Lake. As I watched, it became obvious it was 4 otters, and they jumped in the water and swam away. I heard a noise and looked on the OTHER side of the bridge, and saw 4 more otters swimming toward the bridge. They swam under the bridge and continued to follow the first group, so were there long enough for me to catch a bit of video.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Brush Creek, Santa Rosa, June 27, 2015
properties.Notes: Brush Creek, Santa Rosa, Sonoma County, below the Flat Rock foot bridge, swimming North toward HWY 12
Slide is present.  One of the otters also appeared to be sneezing repeatedly
We have lived here 30+ years and the last time we otters was about 25years ago.
Love them river otters

Otter was in the water, leisurely making its way towards the Beach Road end of the Lagoon. I wasn't close enough to see exactly what it was eating, but it was diving down to the bottom of the Lagoon (about 6-7 feet deep) and bringing up what were clearly tasty treats.

A creek runs right below our deck. I heard a strange sound in the water. Went and got my Mag light. I watched him or her swimming in circles then up and down the little bit of water we have in the creek. Enough though in spots to be up almost to your waist.  It was almost unbelievable, really really exciting.

There were two pups playing and wrestling with each other and a larger otter (we assume the adult) swimming in the pond. When they spotted us, the adult made some warning noises that sounded like bursts of air.
The 2 adults were actively swimming/ diving along the deep side of Lagunitas Creek - upstream ? the 3 youngsters were moving upstream together in the center of the creek.
I saw an otter swimming and diving in a small man made pond.

One small otter seen fishing and eating fish in the middle of the Belvedere Lagoon. He then came up to me on the dock where I was sitting and swam under my feet! Chirping sound. He joined another small otter under my neighbors dock, rolling over each other and playing.
One otter was swimming and diving in the middle of the pond. I didn't see the second one, but could hear it going along the shore in the reeds. I was standing on the trail just above where it was.
Found it floating- dead- in the river while kayaking.
I was fishing in the creek and noted a decrease in the number of fish in the area. I then saw the otters.

There is, I believe, a breeding couple resident in the freshwater pond on the Keil estate. We have regularly sighted adults foraging in the bay shallows and then returning to the Keil pond via the beach. Last year we saw the mother with two pups. This year, they obviously produced 3 offspring. In the past, they have exited the bay directly in front of the pond. This morning, they exited about 50 yards south of the pond, into underbrush, but seemed to be heading for the pond.
Since this first sighting of the summer on June 7, I have several videos of this group of 7 frolicking in this area.

I was riding my bike from the Larskpur ferry, north towards Ross on the paved creek path (daily commute). This was the first time I saw creek otters in over 10 years of riding. Two or three other people also witnessed them.

The otter swam around pool multiple times, diving under occasionally. It was digging/wrestling around the rocks near the edge of the water. It also looked like it was eating something. The otter would climb over and under the broken logs and branches.

On Sunday afternoon a few guests reported an otter siting to me, so i thought I'd let you know. They reported it around 4:40 pm. They said they saw it in a pooling area of Redwood Creek, just across from where the crosscut is located.

He/she was first sighted out on the shoulder of the canal next to the chain link fence that encloses the irrigation canal and slipped into the water when we stopped our bikes in total surprise. We were a mere 15-20 feet away. What a beautifully sleek animal!

I did not know about this site until reading it in the lamorinda times. I will take a photo next time and record it on this site. I live on Las Trampas Creek for the past 22 years. I see otters rarely, but have seen them over the years.
The otter recently seen would submerge and in a minute lift his head up and crunch down on something in his mouth. The crunching was quite audible.
The area is a swamp like area. The otter was on dry ground.
High tide, swimming north. Seen from kayak and paddle board, about 20 feet away.

High-ish (4.0) tide, working edge of island (swimming in water 1-2 ft deep) on channel side, moving north to south along perimeter systematically. Stopped several times to eat something small, couldn't tell if fish, crab, etc.
Playing or feeding (?) on mud bank at water's edge, half in and half out of water
The otters were swimming in the lagoon.
A very small park surrounded by busy street on one side and houses on the other.

Certainly not the first time they have been in the immediate area. They have eaten the fish in a neighbor's pond two houses west of the dock. I saw them years ago in the marsh north of Harbor Cove Way.
Volunteer on creek restoration project Putah Creek Winters CA.

I was crossing over bridge and heard splashing in the reeds that sort of fill the entrance under the bridge. They were whistling at me for sure, very curious. They all swam into the lagoon together so they all entered at the same time. They spotted me right away cause I was whistling back. I had a neon green shirt and think they like it. Took the north way around the bank as I was still observing them and whistling back. They sort of followed me around the bank and I stopped at a wood deck/pier, these lil guys swam under the deck that I was on, and were totally whistling back at me. Got down on my knees looked over deck into the water, they were right under me. Then 3 of them poked their heads out to look for me, I was right over the top of them. They looked super healthy and had beautiful clear eyes. Awesome experience. Have lived here for many years and 1st time seeing 1 and I got to see 5 at once, really stoked about it.
The otters were going from the canal to a nearby irrigation runoff ditch but reversed course when they saw me. I saw a couple of them swimming as I continued my walk
On Contra Costa Canal Trail east of Cherry Lane, At the conjuction of the canal and Walnut Creek. He was in the canal, not the creek.

Man-made lake typically drained in late September. The shore has a small beach on the northeast shore, a dam with some reeds on the west, and larger reed habitat on the south and western shores. It is difficult to identify the presence of a latrine site, shelter or tracks. The observation was of a single otter swimming, head up on the surface for 40-50 ft before submerging. I can't be certain of the life stage of the otter, though I would speculate it was a juvenile. Unfortunately, the otter submerged and disappeared before I could get a photo on my phone.
I see them several times a year. Up until 4 or 5 years ago, I would only see a single otter, but since then always in pairs.
On the dirt "bank" between the fence and the concrete canal edge on the east/south side of the Contra Costa Canal.
Swimming/diving in lake. After spotting humans, they dove and I didn't see them resurface.

I am here because I am concerned about the DISAPPEARANCE of the river otters who have lived here as long as I have, 20 years, until now. They were regular visitors, I saw them at least once a week. I walk my dogs on that channel twice a day. I haven't seen an Otter in over a year now. Two things are happening: People are trapping the crawfish for resale I believe. The other thing that came here was the Graton Rancheria casino. The Channel runs through some of their property. Anyway, I thought that was worth reporting.
Just saw the otters in the water.
I've lived here for 25 years and watch the creek from our second floor windows, and I've seen otters before,occasionally two at once, but never five together. Pretty exciting.

A delightful experience watching these beautiful otters at play while the parents were fishing. Did see one fish caught but it was off at a distance and quickly devoured. I've been there most everyday since getting these images but have not seen them.
They crossed the 13th hole fairway from one pond to the other.

Rylee saw the otter when launching kayaks as part of a summer camp and wanted to report it. It was in the middle of the river, diving down periodically then coming back to the surface. Otter could be seen from the boat launch.
I heard loud chirping outside. Thought I'd see a bird...saw 2 small pups swimming and then up walk over the seawall to eat a fish that had washed up on the rocks.

I am also a 'teacher/professor' at Pacific Union College in Angwin, but I see otters in my capacity as a kayak enthusiast. I am on Lake Hennesey at or near sun-up on half or more of Saturday mornings during the year. I have been seeing otters there at least once a year for the 11 years I have been paddling. My first sighting of one was in the summer of 2004 in the marshy expanse on the east side where the mouth of Chile's/Moore Creek empties into the reservoir. I remember it clearly because I found it so surprising.

The Ranch pond feeds into Spencer Creek that flows into Toulacay and the Napa River. Very far away. Observed them for annual visits over last 3 years. Usually in high water to forage. This is first time I have seen them in low water. Every visit they eat my ducks.
I have noticed these otters before. Normally I have spotted 3 but now there appear to be 2 more that are not quite as large as the other 3.
Crossing from a boggy, former pond area where there is still standing water and lots of frogs, etc., to Murphy Creek, about 100' away over mowed grass. Moving with a rapid, sinuous gallop.
I had no idea that otters were making this strong of a come back. Definitely didn't realize I'd be seeing one daily outside my windows.

I'm describing what I saw last summer, so the date isn't exact.  The otter was trying to come up the concrete dam face, possibly to get bird eggs or some other food that he wanted. Crows kept beating him back. After numerous tries, he gave up, returned to the water, and swam off.  I have seen them swimming and walking on land toward the creek that feeds the lake on other occasions, but don't know the correct dates. I walk there everyday, so it's hard to be precise. I'm told there is a family of them at the reservoir now.
Otters were swimming and vocalizing. Making a 'barking' noise, I assumed directed at myself and my dog. Many signs along the trail the otters had been on land.
First time I have seen them at the reservoir - but I have not been there in a while.
The otter appeared to be alone (I heard that the otter had pups, but did not see any). He/she/it was very active and appeared to be fishing/hunting.

I saw this otter last year, but forgot to report it until I saw another otter in the same area this year. I saw this individual north of our research center while walking my dog. I initially saw it on land but it went into the water once it noticed me walking towards it. I didn't realize it was an otter until it went into the water.
Saw the otter swimming close by shore near our seawall (it's a little north of where our research center is), while walking my dog, wasn't able to get a picture.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Humboldt Bay Wildlife Preserve, February 1, 2016
properties.Notes: Noticed it from the trail about 1/4 mile from visitor center. In the water in shallow marsh area at the refuge. Then climbed out onto the bank near a patch of willows . Sniffed around then re-entered the water headed south toward Hookton road.
Otters were in the water the entire time I was watching them.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Humboldt Bay Wildlife Preserve, February 20, 2016
properties.Notes: Canal, transporting water to various locations in the Refuge.

Went back and forth a couple of times from the Bird Rock (nor sure if that's what it is actually named) area to the smaller rocks a bit north. Did not see out of water. Did not see again after it spotted some people wading near where it was swimming.
In the Americano Estero, on the south side of large open water area. The mouth is closed so no tidal effect today.
Man made pond with fountain, with potential outlet to creek.
Also seen by about 20 excited beachgoers. So much fun to share!

This time the otter looked more like medium sized. It came close, saw us, and then moved back downstream. Hard to spot with all the new tree growth over the creek, but ripples were obvious from under the shore bank (for about 5 min before we saw it well).
Restored section of Redwood Creek; not too deep but many pools in area.

Creek just downstream from footbridge is tidal. Water flow is medium, good color, not too high. Could see otter in riparian along creek, many ripples as it swam, and a very good look at it swam underwater.

This morning was the first time I've seen all seven, they were swimming together, hunting/feeding in the water, vocalizing, and popped up to spy hop" and look at us. They were less than 15 feet from shore."
Otter was seen checking out the floating island biofilters installed by Gallinas Watershed Council.

A backwater pond in the creek, approximately 40ft by 120ft, (created by downstream debris) just downstream from where the trail crosses the creek. We stopped and ate lunch there and suddenly saw the otter. Watched him swim and forage for about 15 minutes. This was a BLM ranger led hike to see bald eagles. The ranger reported that he had not seen otters there before, only on the north fork of Cache Creek, but not on this branch.
Otter was in the creek, poking about the debris that accumulates upstream of the bridge supports. It spotted me right away, dove below the surface & swam west under the bridge.
Otters can frequently be seen swimming together. There are bull rushes along the shore the otters like to hide in. The lakes are stocked with fish and fishing by humans is allowed.

I heard splashing around outside in our pool and looked out and open the window and they scattered very quickly out of the pool and over the fence. I only saw them the one time and it was during the night, so I'm not exactly sure about the number but I didn't see any small ones

I spotted it first in the water vegetation on the south side of the pond. It was diving, then poking up through the vegetation. It did this for awhile, then went up on the bank, walked along the edge of the pond, then slid back into the water. The last I saw of it, it swam to the uphill (east) side of the pond and dived down along the edge of the willows.

I was on a short hike around Jewel Lake with my kids and we saw something in the lake. We thought it was a snake at first but were told that there was a river otter by other walkers. It jumped up on a downed tree in the lake and knocked a turtle that had been there into the lake. After a minute or two it jumped off and continued swimming.
The otter seemed like it was performing for the small group of us watching it. Swimming back and forth and hopping up onto the tree/log that sits in Jewel Lake.

We frequently see river otters swimming around the boats in the Antioch Marina and observe their scat on the docks. The babies are curious about us, and the mother chides them with a chirp when they get too close to people.
Once you cross the bridge and walk up the first hill you come two a couple ponds. We spotted three otters that where very un- phased by our presence. :-)
I was walking my dog just after sunset. The otters were swimming and playing in the lake, diving and surfacing. I watched them for at least 15 minutes.

As we were walking past our pond, I observed a ripple. I was curious, so I watched the spot, and a head appeared. Then he dove, and appeared again a few feet away. His body was now visible. He was watching us for a minute or two and then dived and swam away to a further spot in the pond.
The group was swimming downstream in Willow Creek where they immediately then the entered the lower Russian River.
This a residential area with no nearby creeks that I am aware of. I believe the closest waterway is Pacheco/Walnut Creek.
She did not say what the otter was doing, but did say it was at the pond near her condo.

Initial sighting was from my balcony thru tree branches. Otter came out of pond, dropped fish, which flopped about, I assume Otter ate fish, it was not there later. I went around to far side of pond to get photo and Otter was very aware of my presence, constantly watched me. Was initially on bank of pond then entered water, swam about, stayed under water for long periods. I got bored and left.
We saw them swimming in the creek. We have seen them almost every time we go there once or twice a year.
We saw them swimming in the creek. we have seen them almost every time we go there once or twice a year.

Was surprised to see the animals in the reservoir which I haven't seen in the twenty years I have been walking there. Didn't know what the animal was - otter? beaver? Asked other hikers who were sure they were otters.

Near fuel dock at Benicia Marina- in the fairway on the way out of the marina. Saw 3 of equal size bobbing, diving a presumably fishing. White throats and brown heads. Have also seen dried fish guts and carcasses on the secluded docks
Hard to see from the bridge and no legal access to get a better view. :(

Otter was walking along bank, slid in and submerged upon my approach within about 3'. I routinely see otters in this general area, which is one of my permanent field sites (since 1988). I am filing this report only by request, as Yolo County is not in the Bay Area. Mink and beaver are also present in this area. Muskrats formerly occurred but seem to have disappeared. All 3 egret species, Great Blue Heron, Green Heron and Night Herons occur.

Spotted swimming in a pool above the weir that marks the end of Alameda Creek and the beginning of the Alameda Creek Flood Control Channel (at Niles Staging Area). It quickly dove into the turbid water and disappeared.
Creek running quickly from current rain conditions.
Saw two swimming down stream right below Lagunitas Lake spillway
They were on the meadow right where that small creek goes into Lake. They dove into the water
Man made pond in a well populated and travelled area. I was able to get within 20 feet of it while it sat on a rock, and observed it swimming for over half an hour.
We have observed them multiple times this year and they have visited our pond multiple times over the past 40 years that we have lived here.

A single otter spotted by Bridge 1 by Lucy. A few visitors saw it as well, and about an hour later on the Hillside trail I met some visitors who had seen it, and they commented it was eating a large fish.
He was very active...seemed healthy..adorable.

We saw this otter traveling south on the side of Westside Road. It entered a culvert that was full of water from a creek runoff across the road. The culvert crosses under Westside Road and comes out on my property. I have a winter stream now that flows along the bottom of my hillside and next to Westside Road. We have had over four inches of rain since Monday, and for the first time in years we have runoff and swollen creeks and streams. Perhaps the otter came out of the Russian River, up Dry Creek and started exploring.
The otter looked very content swimming and fishing in the lake.

Inlet where Sunnyside Trail meets Sky Oaks -- emerged from water and 1 appeared to scent mark, returned to water, headed out to open water where they hung out a bit (to the delight of several hikers) :-)
Second time seeing otters in the wild!
Appeared to be hunting
Visible from footbridge. Otter was wary when a dog entered the water at the lagoon edge.
The otter appeared to be alone (I heard that the otter had pups, but did not see any). He/she/it was very active and appeared to be fishing/hunting.

I consider this sighting to be a very special blessing. It is not easy photographing these very fast swimmers (and eaters). I told my friends that is rare to see a full mouth of teeth and that this special Otter must have a very good dental plan to keep those teeth so white! ;-)
We watched them for at least 45 mins. Plenty of Pelicans and Harbor Seals in the water that day too.
River otter was surfacing, swimming a bit and diving.

They crossed from the south side of Remillard Park, over a path, and into the bay, swam to the Larkspur Ferries, and ate fish in front of us. The three were all the same size, not adult in my opinion, probably juveniles. They called to each other when they got split up and regrouped after 2 of them ate fish.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Coast Camp Point Reyes, December 29, 2015
properties.Notes: The otter was foraging in the estuary near the Coast Camp Grounds. It made several visits to and from the estuary. When a large Raven flew overhead, the otter hastily left the estuary and flew on the land from the perceived threat.
Running across Highway 1, while I was entering PT Reyes Station from the north.
Been to this location a number of times but never sighted an otter until today. I was shocked. The little guy was there and gone too fast for the camera.
I watched one otter--and briefly two--in the shallow gravelly area dive for and then crunch crayfish (?) While spouse a few yards up watched 2 play and swim in deeper pool.
Old and new latrine sites at each path they use leaving and entering each pond and the nearby Miller Creek.

I live next to a tributary of San Pablo Creek. I think I have seen an otter very briefly twice before this in recent weeks. On this particular day, I observed him/her eating something in the creek (about 30 feet away) and quickly realized it was one of my pet ducks which apparently he had killed but not been able to pull through the hole in the fence. I and a friend watched him as he then started making his way up the bank of the creek to retrieve more food. We got a good look at him but no pictures. The creek bank is covered with ivy. I haven't seen him since.
I looked for tracks, but the otter was walking through a large puddle parallel to the river, then it slipped into the weeds growing along the river, but did not see it enter the water.

Otter was swimming down stream from the boat launch at Kennedy Park, Napa. It was swimming down the middle of the river foraging and bringing food to the surface. Swam about 1/4 mile downstream from the launch area, then went to the west bank of the river where I lost sight of it.

It was swimming in the canal behind Heather Farms in Walnut Creek. I watched it from the chain link fence. When it saw me, it rolled on it's back and was spitting water. Very playful. It continued to swim along as I walked and it eventually went behind The Keys on Civic Drive.
Saw in Norton Slough, which flows into Foss Creek.

I was at Santa Rosa Taqueria with my two sons ordering lunch.  There is a flood drainage channel that runs parallel to the parking lot.  We saw a large river otter (almost 4 ft) jump out of the drainage channel and run across the parking lot.
I saw one adult river otter swimming on the west side of Lake Ilsanjo.
Small cove with sandy beach where creek reaches ocean.
I saw only tracks, no animals. On a drift log above high tide, several fecal deposits which contained small fish vertebrae, tiny snail shell, fragments of bone or similar material.
This otter did not appear to be full grown and was dead in the road. A turkey vulture was on the curb nearby.
I saw it in Boulder Creek, Just above Sulpher Creek, in some ponds, foraging for food.
They walked through our office complex off the street past our office then down another set of stairs to the street.  Next to the Aurora restaurant
At the intersection of Lakeville Hwy and the north bound 101 on ramp in Petaluma ...otter was dead...hit by a car.
The 2nd one I saw dead was on S McDowell Ext in Petaluma just south of Lakeville Hwy near Schollenberger Park..
Saw the head of an otter while he was swimming.  Also saw what I believe were piles of crayfish shells near the water's edge nearby.
seen on surface 3 times, briefly. mostly underwater.

There is a large pond under the bridge in Glen Ellen. The otter family were mostly swimming in the upper reaches of that pond. They swam under the bridge, heading downstream, occasionally scampering onto the river bank and then back into the pond. They looked like they were foraging, although there was so much playful interaction between the adults and pups it was hard to tell.
Bon Tempe. Took a photo with my camera but really not worth uploading.
Just downstream of the Creamery Rd Bridge (by the Post Office) in San Geronimo
He popped up about 35 feet from shore as I was fishing. Then he swam north and popped up 2 more times.
We last saw otters in this area about 10 years ago.  The creek is high, muddy brown from the rains and flowing fast.  Otters were feeding, curious about humans, shy but not frightened.
Stopped in the water and looked right at me and my dog!

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, March 16, 2016
properties.Notes: Area is flooded from recent rains, nothing but water and some submerged bushes were observed.
It was swimming along the dam following me.
One adult - big! - on the bank grooming himself.
Family group swimming.  Latrine site in area. Observed while kayaking. Have not seen the group since 2014
Near the sea wall at Loch Lomond Marina - in the Bay
2 adult otters swimming
It seems to be disturbing the mallard ducks.
I've never seen them here in my neighborhood! Was swimming alongside a man-made dam near a culvert.
Middle pond at Mountain View cemetery.

properties.Description: 4 Otter - Las Gallinas Wildlife Pond, May 27, 2016
properties.Notes: The pups were sub adults, nearly the same size as the adults. First I saw one adult, it swam into the n/e corner of pond#1 into cattail reeds. It re-emerged with three other otters.
This is the second time I have seen this otter, the other time was 4 weeks ago.
They were playing on my boat dock.

The otter was swimming to the left side in the cove (from the shore) inbetween the moored saiboats and the rip rap. He was diving and swimming about for about 20mins before we lost sight of him. We also didn't see if he had caught anything to eat!

The mom was trying to move the pups and got scared when she saw me so I tried not to scare her and moved away. I have video of mom and two of the three pups as she hid one. We live across the street from the bay. At first I thought they were ferrets but then realized they were otters.
Although I had binoculars, I could not tell when the otter was eating but he was diving, coming up and clearly eating something and then diving down again, coming up eating
It was laying in the sun for quite a while, even with people walking nearby. The fur is drying and there are no water marks around it on the dock.
No tracks, slide, or latrine sight.  Just a splash followed by the unmistakable nose, eyes, & ears poking above water's surface staring at me as I went by.
The otter was adult size and was seen running behind a building on property.
Within 20 ft of the bank.The bank consists of rock rip-rap. I also saw a river otter in this same location in Nov.2010.
High traffic park trail
Crossing the road near creeks and ocean
The Otter was in lake across the street where stream meets lake and a small section was not frozen
crossing road
Oak woodland!! 1/2 mile from the nearest creek and 3/4 mile from the nearest pond
In the creek that runs parallel to Miller Ave
Along the Canal in San Rafael at low tide. Swam across canal and out onto mud below building foraging on clams, etc on exposed cement pilings. Then swam back towords bay along shoreline.
Walking around on property at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Seen walking along the road within the park. Then it walked off towards Lake Chabot

River otter was spotted at Alpine Lake in Marin, CA. I only caught a 5 second glimpse of it before it was gone. We were fishing near a small bridge where the creek flowed into the lake and I was able to see the Otter scurry down the creek slighlty out of the water and make its way into the lake before it was gone. It was a smaller otter about the shape of a racoon or large cat. Very exciting!
I did not observe any tracks or other evidence of otters.

My dog was swimming - fetching his ball.  The river otter surfaced and appeared to chase the dog.  At first I thought it might be a mother defending a near by litter, but on further observation, it appeared the little guy just wanted to play with my golden retriever.
Came running out of the ocean onto the beach. Then scrambling over rocks.
50 feet off shore swimming fast toward Golden Gate - otter was at least 4 ft long
Pond behind Tiburon Town Hall
Beach at Kirby Cove, ran into the water
Side of road. Near Creek. Creek is flanked by 2 very busy roads. (Highway 29 and Solano) otter slipped into brush when it saw my car.
It was near the bridge that leads from the road to Rodeo Beach. It swam toward the ocean and then turned around. It came out of the water to either pee or defecate and have a long dust bath.
They were 'attached' and sloshing around the western side of Bon Tempe Lake.  They were definitely mating.

The otter was in my garage this morning! I went to get in the car and almost stepped on him. He ran out of the garage very fast and into the bushes in my neighbors yard. I live very close to the Contra Costa Canal (it's just beyond our back fence) and I saw one swimming in the canal in August 2015, too.
Swimming in the Contral Costa Canal.
In lake Chabot next to the dock at the life support office which is next to Chabot Stadium.There was scat on the dock.
After swimming and eating for a while, the otter disappeared into the reeds near a bushy vegetated area near the bridge. Maybe its holt was nearby?
It was between 3-4 Ft. long and was chasing a couple of mallards.  We have seen crayfish, bullfrogs and turtles in this drainage.  First time we saw a river otter.  Super cool!
I watched them mate in the lagoon behind drakes beach parking lot day before yesterday. Was pretty wild. Went on for a long time, maybe 20 minutes before I left them to it?
Very low water level and flow, probably 2-3 cfs. So otter was barely able to submerge. Lived here thirty years and this is my first sighting in my creek.

The otter successfully ran in front of my car, crossing the Pt Reyes-Petaluma Rd along the Nicasio Reservoir. S/he was large adult, dark in color.In 30 years of driving in Marin and Sonoma this is my first sighting of an otter along a roadway. Exciting for me. Dangerous for the otter.
Met it at top of concrete steps to my back yard it turned around and slid down them to bottom. Was it foraging, looking around or what, I don't know
He/she was in our backyard swimming pool. Our small backyard backs up onto Benicia Community Park, open space and Lake Hermann is not far. The otter came to swim two nights in a row.
Swimming in the lake

About 0.25 mile upstream of Monte Rio beach on Russian River. It was collecting food from the bottom and eating on the go in the river. Could not tell what food source but not fish. It was picking items off of the bottom. Perhaps crayfish.

I was on my paddle board so about 25 ft away. It was hard to tell what exactly it was doing, but looked like he was moving around on the rocks right by the shore. Probably looking for crabs? (it was that close to the water's edge. After about a minute it scurried into the water and I never saw it again.
In the Canal water swimming West. Bobbed up to see me through the fence and would dive again as I walked along on the bike path. I turned off at Lusherm to Cherry Lane.

Otters swam along bank of estero toward Home Bay. The 5 of them split-up (one mom and pup stayed, while the other 3 continued). The 2 that stayed went ashore for awhile, then the mother left the pup on shore when she chased fish
Tracks, latrine site, scat
Near a beachy area- when the tide is half in/half out there are beachy areas on the south side of Kennedy Park. I saw the otter swimming in the center of the river heading south.
just saw swimming alone
playing on a old dock
Mother was showing pup how to eat a dead fish

We have 2 acres bordering a vineyard.  Heard animal noises over the back fence.  Shocked to see 2 river otters!  One made its way down the dirt road heading west back towards Green Valley Creek.  The other one snuck through a gap in our fence, meandered through our walnut orchard and then made its way to Jeni Lane and turned west heading toward the creek.  Hadnt seen otters since we rafted the Rogue River.  Very cute!  They looked sleek and healthy.

I initially saw an adult leading 3 almost grown young, swimming and foraging N on the slough from a distance of 20-30 feet. Walked parallel to them for 8-10 minutes, then lost sight as the explored a narrow tributary. I first spotted them because of .low, muttered grunting sounds. On the way back, I saw a significantly larger adult emerge from a side slough. He(?) came head and shoulders out of the water and breathed loudly at me. He then started N on the main slough, and 5 seconds behind him, the other adult and 3 pups followed, clearly associated.

Observed rolling , rubbing on small dock. some low vocalisations . Otter was extremely curious and observed us closely as we watched from about 15 ft. The otter was obviously aware of our presence and had extreme eye contact during the encounter. He defecated on the dock and dove off.
we only saw them swimming this time but other times we have seen them climb up on an island and walk there

properties.Description: 1 Otter - tennessee Valley Beach Lagoon September 5, 2015
properties.Notes: Otter was on far side of the lagoon just before TV beach.  Had binoculars so could see him/her close up.  Was swimming around and then went over to far side and didn't see the otter come back up in the water or see it on the shore
Appeared to be hunting - repeatedly diving and coming up and eating but, I don't believe it could have been eating fish - I assumed it was eating plant matter.
it's just a lagoon behind our house where people aren't supposed to walk.  they were heading west towards an area where they can be seen from the path in Spinnaker Point

properties.Description: 1 Otter - tennessee Valley Beach Lagoon, March 19, 2015

properties.Notes: Observed for 10-15 minutes. It was not disturbed by our presence (though we were 15 feet away above the creek on the bank of the creek. We heard it first then spotted that it was an otter.
They seemed rather small but all were very close in size. Maybe they were around 24 inches long and slender.

He/she? was at the far end of the pond by the beaver damn. Initially he was on land and when he saw me he hid behind a bush. Than he slipped into the water and I was able to follow the movement underwater until he surfaced about 20 feet from the bank. He kind of rolled over on his back and took a good look at me before diving underwater again and swimming to a further away location that I could not track. Though I had my camera with me I was not able to get a picture of him but I'm sure it was not the local beaver. He was too long and did not have a beaver tail. There was some scat near where he entered the water that I could collect if that would be of some help.
Swimming and eating something in the water. Then he climbed up on the dock and rolled around for a while and walked all over the dock.
Often see scat with crayfish shell pieces. Edge of small shallow pond covered with Azolla and plant growth. Pond is spring fed with trickle runoff into Crane Creek.
They swam up and down the river in the middle of the river channel and into the canal behind the house.

it was on edge of the levee road .. I..stopped and examined it..it was mobile but seemed slow and lost... and when I approached it hissed at me like a feral cat. It's eyes seemed sealed shut and it curled up in a submissive ball in the brush...glossy brown fur, no markings. surprised to see it...been living on the delta for 10 + years..seen a couple in the water swimming, but this was a pup up on the roadway.. and seemed to be lost...maybe couldn't find a way back down to the water..
