I left it and it curled up in a ball under some brush.

I observed the otters for about 10 minutes. Otters were swimming in the river, they dove down several times but I was not able to observe if they were feeding. They noticed me on shore and made a soft huffing noise towards me, but did not seem bothered by me.

The otters were swimming near the east bank of the Napa River at high tide.  The flood plain in this area is fairly shallow. They appeared to be "working" the area next to the rush margin of the river. Talking to the fishermen that are generally in this spot each morning the otters have been regularly seen.
Otter out scouting after light rain after long drought.  Very happy.  Left little wet otter prints on my front porch and then skittered away up the street.

They are in walnut creek behind our community (Pleasant Hill cohousing) and we see them almost every year. I have taken pictures this year. They go up the bank and cover themselves in soil and hang out in the sun, then come back into teh water and play for a while. The parents were teaching the two pups to dive and swim across the stream and we saw one parent go up the bank to her two pups. It has been incredible to see to otters. Someitmes they hide in the storm drain holes and peek out at us. They seem to be very curious and swim along as we walk along the bank on the flood control district road (this is NOT a public road). We have been seeing them for over a month now, but I have seen only 4 in the past couple of weeks.
The otter / seal poked his head out as we were sailing and observed our boat from about 30 feet away. Seemed curious but we didn't want to approach it.
Visible from footbridge. Otter was wary when a dog entered the water at the lagoon edge.

The otter was slurping down fish so fast. He must have eaten several while we were watching him swim, dive and eat. There is a lot of food there. Shiners, the silver bait fish and oysters and clams and mussels.

There are tracks on the bank where you can tell that it is the main route for the otter to come out of the water. The grass is matted down and there are multiple, visible holts on the bank of the stream.
Scampering and frolicking on sand dunes. Observed one adult eating a bird, chomping on bones and flesh.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - UC Davis Arboretum canal, September 16, 2015
properties.Notes: They appeared to be hunting ducks. As I was walking down the path a large group of ducks got startled and fled the water. I then saw an otter chasing them up the hill while the second otter was swimming.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Kings Range National Conservation Area, October 3, 2015
properties.Notes: They looked like they had been sleeping there over night and came out to see what the we (the campers) were up to.

Temescal Creek is in my backyard. I suspect the otter was in my yard  the night of the 8th because my dogs were very excited. The otter was hiding in the ivy. Eventually it crawled under two fences going north towards Lake Temescal on land around 2:00 pm.  I have lived on Temescal Creek 19 years and never seen an otter before. It was a delightful, magical experience.  Besides the otter I also had a Nuthatch in the house today. It's never boring on the creek.

Otters stayed/played together as a group on the edge of a sand dune that runs directly into the water that was one of the few spots clear of aquatic vegetation. Adults appeared to be content sunning themselves in warm sun and sand. Juveniles were much more playful. One juvenile observed sliding about 10 feet down the sand dune headfirst on its belly.

the three otters swam around for about 15 minutes then climbed out on the bank and played for about 5 minutes before returning to the water.  I would say these were young otters---maybe teenagers, as they were quit e a bit smaller than the ones we usually see.

The otter was in front of our house, walking along and stopping here and there to lay down, as if looking for a nice spot to rest. Didn't seem in distress, although troubling that it was so close to the street. We have a creek running thru our backyard, which flows down into nearby Lake Temescal (1/2 mi away). Otters known to live there. Nearby neighbors have also spotted an otter in last several days. We're just concerned that s/he may get hurt by a passing car since s/he's getting close to the street.
They were swimming quickly, not eating or playing.
Dead on the side of the road.  It appears to be their short cut from the BMK lagoons to the Novato Creek.

I'm part of an urban-mushing group which runs our dogs on the creekside trails in the Santa Rosa area every weekend.  A few weeks back, we saw what I was sure was otter scat by a pond alongside Santa Rosa Creek, out by Willowside Road.  This morning we confirmed it when we saw two adult otters swimming, eating and walking along the bank four miles East of there, almost into downtown Santa Rosa.  So it's confirmed; we have otters in Santa Rosa Creek!

We see this group of otters every week now, when I run my dogs with the sulky before dawn, by helmet light, one day every week there.  I don't bother trying to catch photos or videos anymore, because I usually spot them by the reflection of my helmet light from their eyes, stop to say hi but it's too dark to film. We have seen them in all three ponds, fishing, eating, crossing the trails.  This particular spot is one of their overnight haul-outs, it was obvious as they took to the water upon our approach and the trail was totally soaked where they had been laying, and the dogs' excited sniffing behavior made it clear they'd been on the ground for quite some time.  We have had them take to the water several times when we passed this specific place, and seen them out in the water as we've passed this spot. I have only seen five or less every time I have spotted them, but I talked to two women regulars that day who have seen seven walk across the trail from one pond to another, and spoke to another regular out there who said he saw seven in the creek next to the ponds.  They are now being seen regularly before, at and even after sunrise by numerous people, fishing and eating.

Relatively low water in 1930's era channelized (stone & cement) creek bed. The deepest part for a mile or so, is in our yard and about 2.5 feet deep. Big boulders, lots of vegetation, with fish, frogs and crawfish. This is the first sighting of River Otters since we've lived here (3 years).

I had some dry cat food out in my front yard for a neighborhood I.  I went out front and spotted, stunningly, an otter eating it.  I ran inside to graby my camera but he moved up on the street.  I followed up but got blocked by a car trying to avoid hitting him.  He then moved under a car when he was confronted by a cat and then scattered down the hill.  I have no tracks or photos unfortunately.  But the nearest creek is probably about a half mile away.  So it was very unexpected.

After hiking to Sunset Beach we walked along the shore toward the end of Drakes Head. At that end we saw the 3 otters in the water and then noticed their paw prints on the sand at that  place. They might have been sunning/playing on that shore and we spooked them into the water. After us all looking at each other for a while, they swam back toward Sunset Beach.

We were on the ridge picnic table overlooking the creek and were shocked to see otters playing and swimming below. The park usually has a good amount of people in it during the day- it is a popular location for team sports.

We were kayaking and came across an area with reeds and good protection. We saw four otters playing in and out of the water near shore. We saw them grooming. Further down we saw three more (maybe the same) swimming or fishing in the main channel. There was another well-protected inlet where we saw an otter swimming.
It looked like they were frolicking for fish goodies.

We saw one otter scurrying along the beach. It may have come from the body of water (river?) near the Tennessee Beach. We observed it walking/running toward the water, then into the ocean. It swam near the shore and towards the cliffs for about 3 or 4 minutes then we lost sight of it.
They were mostly observing the two of us in kayaks.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - North fork Cosumnes River, November 4, 2015
properties.Notes: Otters were swimming back and forth over a 200-300 foot area and diving where the river is 4 to 8 feet deep

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, November 8, 2015
1 Otter - Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, November 8, 2015

properties.Notes: Crew working on the trail had seen them in the pond earlier that morning.

My wife spotted them while we we SUPing today. Three otters, two got out of water on to dead/fallen tree and got back in. A third one was eating a fish while in the water. We observed them for about 5-10 min.  Lots of people walking around the lake today, we were the only ones on the water. Great to see.

These otters live on Toulocay Creek where it enters the Napa River. I have seen these otters go all the way up Millikan Creek to the diversion dam about a half mile up from Westgate Dr at Silverado Country Club.   They also forage through Collector Canal on the Napa River south of Imola at least once a week.  Typically at sunset, late at night, or sunrise.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, November 8, 2015
properties.Notes: The otter was crossing the road as I was driving into the parking area. It was about 20 feet in front of my car. I stopped on the road and grabbed my binocs, and watched it turn around and head back to the bank it had come from. And then it crawled in the water and swam and dove several times. It was huge (somewhere between 3 and 4 feet).

We see river otters in our backyard once a year. Las Trampas Creek goes through our backyard. We have not seen a siting this year but two years ago, my daughter and I followed a family of four downstream ~quarter of a mile to where they climbed into a drainage culvert. This is the first summer we have not seen them but I don't work at home.

My mom and I were on the Dam Trail at Lake Temescal, sitting on a bench looking out over Lake Temescal.  The otter was swimming towards shore (towards us).   I went over to the steeply sloped shoreline to see where the otter was headed, but I couldn't see the edge of the lake because of the shrubs.  The shore at this edge of the lake is dammed so maybe it was swimming towards a den?
The otter was sunning himself/herself on the bank of the river/water canal.

Then he swam under bridge and headed west toward Tennessee Valley, with the rising tide. He swam under water then resurfaced four or so times so I watched the bubbles. I assume that is foraging behavior.

The pond is connected to the bay by some kind of drainage channel. Appeared to be all the same size but could not tell for sure. The one in the photo appeared to be eating something while sitting on the sandbar in the pond as shown in the photo. This is the second time in two weeks I have seen three otters in the pond. There did not appear to be tracks or anything else indicating their presence.
Very healthy, happy, playfull in pond.
It come out to feed on a washed up log and returned to hunting for fish. I didn't notice any tracks, etc on the bank.
I observed the animal from across the water so I could not see any tracks, etc.

There is no water nearby except for a small creek several hundred yards away. The otter is situated under a shed, occasionally moving around. I do have poor quality video but the file size is quite large.
One climbed out on a rock to eat, the other stayed in the water.

I have spotted otters in this area of Pacheco Creek at this time of year for the past 3 years. I usually see mothers and their young. I may have located a day den in this area. It seems that they use this den each year.
There are weekend homes on both side of the river, but not very dense. Lush foliage and vegetation. Quiet, no busy roads nearby.
They was an incredible experience as this otter was only 3-4 feet away from me. I was able to observe it at a latrine site for about 15 minutes. It marked, rolled, chuffed.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Arroyo Corte Madera del Presidio, July 21, 2016

properties.Notes: Swimming close together very close to public dock.
These two were very curious as to what I was doing. They vocalized quit a bit at my presence. They stuck around for about 10 minutes then headed back down the slough towards Moorehead Marsh.

Observed swimming and catching a large trout. Then, swam onto a partially submerged log with fish and dropped it twice and had to re-catch it as it tried to swim away. Eventually ate it, tail first. Then swam away.
They looked happy and healthy and we were thrilled to see them!

Appears that they might be living under the hold Valhalla restaurant. They were swimming along the coast and seemed pretty determined to get out of the water there. Observed them run under the pilings of the building from the water.
Otter was hanging out in Alhambra creek where the beavers used to come to take down trees.

Many people were calling them sea otters but they never floated on their backs and generally exhibited playful river otter behavior. They were a little large for river otters though, interesting either way!

The Contra Costa Canal is a man-made concrete aqueduct with a multiuse trail next to it, separated by a cyclone fence. River otters have been using it to move between Hidden Lakes in Martinez, Heather Farm pond in WC, and other points.

It was in the ditch between the Cal Trans maintenance station and the offices near the Holiday Inn just north of Manzanita Park and Ride. I was on the sidewalk on the north side of shoreline and the otter (large adult) was working along the bank of the ditch about 30yds north of me. It came out of the water to cross a gravel bar headed north so I go a clear look at it out of the water and it was definitely an adult river otter.
Large tidal pool alongside the Tennessee Valley hiking trail

The mother (was able to see pronounced nipples on the belly) was attending three pups that were maybe a little more than half her size. When I first saw them, they were all rolling and sliding in the sand, as if taking a sand bath, all the while playing with one another (e.g., the pups would nibble and jump on the mom while sliding around).

We observed the River otter running from the direction of Pierce Point Road and the Abbott's Lagoon trailhead, towards the first small pond that is south of the Abbott's Lagoon trail, going through a large amount of pasture land.
Sunning itself on side of creek
Loved seeing these beautiful creatures on our morning walk. Have never seen them in 12 years of living here!

It was really surprising and fun seeing them! They were in the middle of a big conversation - chattering about something. They were foraging a bit at the shore but also swimming in a fun and relaxed manner. They went underwater in a hurry (toward the bridge) as soon as they saw me watching them.
Sighting was observed by other campers that same morning.

In the channel which deadends parallel along the Moffett Slough, we observed a solitary otter swimming for about 100 feet. It then flipped and dove, and presumably entered a nest somewhere since we did not see it come up nearby after several minutes.

The were swimming and splashing, and then rummaging/rolling on the muddy banks of the creek. There were a number of birds accompanying them, so I have to assume they were rummaging up creatures that they were all partaking of! I don't know if there are tracks or slides.
We saw them from a building above the dock. They looked young and appeared to be playing. They were very sleek looking and looked small - certainly much smaller than sea otters.

properties.Description: 10 Otters - Laguna De Santa Rosa, March 10, 2016
properties.Notes: Early morning sighting of around 10 different otters swimming and bobbing up and moving together.

properties.Description: 2 Otters - Laguna De Santa Rosa, November 9, 2015

properties.Notes: The otter was running along the beach

Walking across the Park Street Bridge, I saw the River Otter swimming and eating (sardines?) below in the water, near the eastern/Oakland shore. It was moving up towards the Fruitvale Bridge and the large stream that empties into the estuary there. It seemed to be happy and having a good time, as it was rolling and looking around a lot. I watched it until it reached the UCB Crew Boathouse, and then it submerged for a long time and I lost sight of it.

I was sitting on the lawn near the ferry in Jack London Square, and saw the Otter swim by, about 30 feet off the shore. This Otter was on a mission, swimming quickly. It looked right at me (or my sandwich), and looked all around, checking out its surroundings. It was headed up the estuary towards the Fruitvale. Within a couple minutes it was out of sight. Very pleasant but odd to see it near all the shipping traffic.
Four otters came out from under a large rock on the beach at ACR's Cypress Grove Preserve on Tomales Bay.
Otters were spotted right below trail to Elephant Seal observation area.
Running along highway, turned around and headed back toward Coyote Creek/Bay

The otters were eating eel like fish, thats what it looked like. Holding their heads toward the sky and eating. The otters did not appear concerned about us - we were in kayaks and there were two people on shore ( we did not know these people, they were keeping their distance).

The mother otter was seemingly tired, she appeared to have her eyes closed or squinting most of the time that we were there (watching from our kayaks). The mother didn't move much - I interpreted that to mean that she was tired? She did not seem concerned about us. The pups were watchful and seemed a little guarded.
Was not alarmed at sighting me, but casually swam within 10' and then dove underwater.

I was in a rowing shell and they were on the rip rap when I first saw them. One of the pups was eating a small white fish and the other two were engaging with one another and exploring the rocks. As I and my companion rowed past the otters, the adult and the non-eating pup walked across the rocks in our direction then slid into the water.  They swam half-way toward my boat where I was sitting with my oars still. The young otter kept attempting to ride on the back of the adult. The adult would soon dive under the water's surface and the pup would resume swimming along on its own.
I've never seen them here ! Very excited!
Saw 4 otters swimming around the docks on the cove. This is the second time we have seen them.
There have been other sightings of 4 together recently and last winter they had pups.
I watched them play for 20 minutes. Two swam up within ten feet of me.

I keep a natural sighting diary in which I record interesting events.  I had been hoping to see an otter one day but until that event I had only seen river rats. I heard thrashing in the creek but couldn't see what.  I realzed it was making its way through the cat tails to the edge of the creek.  I was  scared but I stood very nearby.  It thrust its head through the reeds and I was stunned when I saw its leathery nose and its big muzzle full of whiskers. I realized that this was  an otter.  He turned around to leave and I saw his tail.
Seen offshore with a spotting scope. The group was travelling eastward.
Swimming Northeast in the middle of the river after exiting from storm drain channel on north side of river
In a well maintained community pond
I saw the otter swimming near the trestle bridge in civic park, walnut creek.
I normally spot otters at this location in the mornings. This is the first-afternoon sighting.
A group of five otters was seen in the same location last year and the year before.  This year one lone otter was also seen occationally feeding and swimming under docks.
Santa Rosa creek trail to Delta Pond off of Willowside Road on the southwest side.
Sonoma Creek just playing in the water. There is a steep embankment so they did not see us watching them.
Family group swimming and diving close to shore, following the shoreline, close family group; observed from trail the leads to bay from parking lot

He has been in that location before. It's been many months. He comes out from the drain into the creek. He was walking in the shallow water one direction, changed direction and went into the deeper water.
We get all kinds of wildlife activity in our creek. This is the third or fourth time we've seen otters over that last two years.  Before it has been in pairs and once with two pups.
Second hand report of information giving to the Rescue Department at The Marine Mammal Center in Sausalito, CA
At the mouth of Estero Americano (mouth was closed by sand)
I have seen otters here before.

The otter was swimming and foraging in canal, then climbing up on embankment, then going back into canal. I watched it do this 3 times. I also saw it defecate and groom. I've seen an otter in the canal several times but this is the first time I've had a chance to see it so close and take pictures. There are a lot of people on the trail who are enjoying watching the otter. I think dozens - maybe hundreds of people - have seen this otter.  It may be an opportunity to educate the public about river otters.
Swimming in the lagoon right before Tennessee Valley beach.

properties.Description: 4 Otters - Winters Putah Creek Nature Park, October 5, 2016
properties.Notes: I saw these four otters in Putah Creek in Winters, CA (95694), in a not-yet-restored section of the creek. This part of Putah Creek is in the Winters Putah Creek Nature Park. All four were together in a group, diving down and coming up with food (looked like crawdads). They also went on land on both sides of the creek; one side looked like it has otter slides. I've been seeing otters there for over 10 years. This particular location is in a reach that is slated for restoration/realignment and is between restored sections, but work has not yet started. There are one or two likely short slides on the south bank of Putah Creek in this exact location; one or two otters walked on them (I'm not sure if they actually slid).
5 biologists were there with photographs
Four similar-sized otters swimming along the edge of the pond and foraging in the reeds.  They may have all been young, they were not the biggest otters I have ever seen.
across the street from the Cascade Falls parking area in the creek below.
I have just started paddle boarding on Lake Solano and see otters about 50% of the time.  Singles up to a group of 6.

Three otters were eating bait fish(herring), 2 swam towards docks, Third one chirped and other two came back. A dog was climbing on the rocks on the shore. Every time the dog turned its back to the otters, two of the otters would swim towards the dog. The otters climbed on the docks, but swam off when sailing people walked down ramp to their sailboat. Otters swam towards Mill Valley.
The otter has been seen on two occasions.  Todays sighting was between the dock and shore on west side of harbor near Harbor Masters office, swimming out towards Bay.
This was along the Contra Costa Canal trail.  The otter was in the grasses next to the canal, periodically moving in and out of the water.
The otters were eating carp
Dead, adult, male river otter on east side of Franklin-Hood Road just before Stone Lake NWR.
A group of 6 headed upstream.

I saw the 2 otters along the Prince Memorial Greenway when I was riding my bike. I was about 50 feet from the otter. I was up on the path and they were below me in the water and on the bank of the creek. Seeing these otters made my day!!
Observed for three days.. Swimming, resting on pump float, playing. Also observed catching and eating western pond turtles.
I saw the otters in some deep pools of water after recent rains. They also hauled out on the bank for a short period of time.
It was on the sidewalk but the Laguna de Santa Rosa land is directly next to the sidewalk.

It was cool to see! I didn't know there were otters in the bay!  The site there is home to lots of wildlife.  Last week I saw a bay ray, I sometimes see sea lions, and there are neat birds like white pelicans, egrets, and sand pipers. At first I thought it might be a seal until it did a little dive and I saw the tail and how small it was.
This is the third time I've seen this otter at the same pond.

It was exploring the south branch of the creek on the downstream side from where it flows under Talbot avenue. I lost sight of it after 3-4 minutes. Perhaps it moved upstream under the bridge where I couldn't see it.
I observed them swimming around my docked boat. It was my first time seeing them here.
One of the four otters walked up the dock to the end of my boat! It stood there and looked at me for a few minutes before it slid back into the water.

It was at the shoreline in rushes. I thought it was a turtle or large snake but it looked to have fur. It circled round and slipped into water. When it popped up in the water I saw head, neck and upper shoulder area.
We stopped our boat and cut the engine to observe. They were extremely playful in the water before they decided to climb out.
They climbed out of the water on the bank just south of Pebble Beach on Tomales Bay
It was surfacing and diving a couple of times amongst the water weeds near the reeds. I was in my kayak, headed for the launch ramp after about an hour on the lake.

The otter was present in the canal area for about a week.  I witnessed it eat a large crayfish and regularly hunt for small fish (minnow sized) in the aquatic plants that grow on the edges of the canal.  When the otter showed up all the Mallards that are regular inhabitants of the canal disappeared.  I saw the otter crawl into a culvert that provided access to the area beyond the chain link fence.

It was in a reach of Sonoma Creek upstream and downstream of the Glen Ellen bridge. Several hundred yards total. The otter swam up and down several times, then got out of the water under the bridge and rolled in the dirt.
They seemed to be playing in the water, then got out and walked up the dry creek bed of Calabazas Creek.
The otters made their appearance at the beginning of a canoe tour I was co-leading for Lake Solano Park/Putah Creek Council, and I'm very grateful to the otters for making the outing so successful!

The three pups were playing under the giant LWD and the mom was in the bushes to the right of the log when we first arrived. After 5 minutes she came out and gathered them up and disappeared into the bushes.
The otter was chasing a later eating a salmon (the first one of the season). The salmon must have been a chinook because it was HUGE. It then took the rest of the salmon up stream.
They were in the water, by the rocks.  One jumped on a rock just for a few seconds

From the bridge, a group of us watched this family of river otters swimming in San Pablo Creek. The otters didn't seem to mind us as they swam up and down the creek and climbed atop a fallen tree, about 20-30 feet (and 10 feet below) from us.
Two otters were on lagoon dock wile the other 3 were in water. I see this group periodically while paddle boarding.
I frequently see otters hunting water birds with an underwater approach. This is the first time I've seen one try a frontal charge on foot.
The otter was eating a sting ray. A crow vocalizing scared them and they took their fish to the lagoon and ate under the bush.

Otter was viewed during a site visit between contractor (reporter) and Napa County Flood Control staff.  Later in the day a private landowner upstream of the location reported that a "family with multiple pups" was seen moving back in forth in the area for "some days."

I saw the otter move out from the brush on the hillside across the mud at low tide and then enter the bay and start swimming. The otter swam off in one direction for awhile and then stopped in one area and began to fish and forage for food.

It's Coyote Creek.  This portion of the creek is dry twice a day, and full twice a day.  The otter appears to have a place under the boardwalk where it stays when the water is low or gone.  I've seen it several times in the last few weeks, but only today got a good enough look at it to be sure I was staring at an otter.  Sometimes when I've biked down this boardwalk, I've seen what looks like a trail through the mud to under the boardwalk.  Each sighting was in about the same spot.
I was so excited to see them! In 27 years of hiking I had never seen otters in Marin!
Spotted 4 large otters feeding along the shoreline. Such fun to watch them frolic and having breakfast.
I was on my lunch break and I saw a group of 6-7 otters running down the bank and slid into the water. They looked about the same size.
I'm new to the area and this was my first sighting near my house.  They were definitely river otters because I have photographed them elsewhere before.  Great job on the river otter project!

They stopped at the big logs just downstream from the culvert and looked at us standing up on the trail.  They were very fast swimming up, but clearly checking every pool.   They must have turned around after climbing around on the log pile for a minute.   We continued up the trail a little and then came back down and did not see them again.   There were clearly 6 and all seemed the same size.   From where we stood, other details were not obvious and we didn't have binoculars with us.

I was out with my family walking on a trail we walk on just about every day when we spotted this family of otters. We were blown away. We've lived here for years and I've never seen anything like it. There are always lots of birds in the creek but never otters. I had no idea they could live in a smallish creek. We watched them from a distance for a few minutes before leaving them alone. They were amazing!
Yes, it was a real freaking OTTER.  Best day in a a long time.  A river OTTER in Vallejo!
We have fallen in love with these cute lil creatures.
When he was swimming he stuck his head out of the water and looked at us.
Wonderful to see otters on this walk. Have never seen them before here.
Any day I wake up an see river otters is a good day.

The creek behind our house has fairly high banks and is wooded.  We frequently see wildlife including deer, egrets, herons, raccoons, variety of song birds, sometimes hawks an occasional owl. I'm not sure what the otter was feeding on but he went up to several areas of the vine covered bank put his head underneath and came out with something in his mouth, tilting his head up to swallow it.  Then he glided over to another spot and did the same.  After a few minutes he went back up stream from where he came.  He appeared healthy and energetic.

I watched a for a few minutes while he/she went in and out of the water twice and swam towards Broadway. If there was another, it may have already gone around the corner, but I only saw one. I have never seen one there before, but I did talk to an employee who has seen them there a few times. There a lot of Canada geese there, mallards, and lots of other birds (mergansers, egrets, herons, etc.). I once saw a squirrel swimming across the creek there too! Great place in the middle of town to watch wildlife!

They were several yards from the water, up near the shoulder of the road on a rainy day. I spooked them as I came around a bend in view on my bicycle. They scrambled to the water, then all resurfaced and looked back at me, snorting and such. Then swam off across the lake.
They were in the lake in my backyard, diving then eating small fish on the surface; one otter caught a bigger fish and took it to land and ate the fish then went back to lake for more foraging
Sooo cool to see them. We heard them before we saw them, and they were definitely watching us.

I hope these are not the mother and 3 cubs seen earlier this summer and autumn in the same location. If so the mother might be down one pup. Viewed the otters from about 50 yards away. Initially thought they were sea otters because they were in the ocean. After speaking to a ranger and checking my pictures I correctly identified them as river otters.
So exciting!

The group didn't seem as shy of me as I would have expected. I've seen lots of seals and sea lions that area, but they stay 30 feet off shore and don't show any awareness of me walking that path. The otters were right at the edge of the shore, and they made eye contact with me. I hope that's just their nature and doesn't mean someone's feeding them.
This is the fourth or fifth sighting by members of our kayak club in Vallejo.  The otters are very shy, and submerge themselves as soon as they realize they are being watched.
We were in such awe that we didn't think to get our cameras out.
It's great to see these little guys making a come back. Was very unexpected to see him swimming along without a care in the world
The same day I saw a hawk taking a prey on the dock.  It's great to see animals thrive.
I love otters.
On the shore of the big sand dune, and then in the water of the upper lagoon fairly near the bridge and channel.
In the water among the reeds right where what looks to be an old boat launch or access road meets the water from the trail junction.
It looked at me from 20' away and went underwater/popped up 3 times; last time cocking its head back slightly and quietly chirped at me. Then gone.
Boat dock.
This was the second time in the past 2-3 months I've seen river otters swim toward and climb into a reddish culvert pipe that empties into Bon Tempe Lake.

Otter was swimming at the surface, with eyes and nose out of the water.  Seemed to notice me and proceeded to dive and swim submerged upstream.  I followed on my bike on the trail higher up on the bank.  It surfaced and swam around more.  It dove again and I left.It stayed in the water, so it was very difficult to judge its size with no reference objects.
Seen on the move along the river bed and then swimming upstream towards the dam.

They were seen around and atop a low tide-emerged barrel near the elephant seal colony.  Killed prey (gull?), dragged prey on to barrel, ate prey.  They swam over to 1st pier and spent a lot of time playing around there before the kill/feast.
The otter was on the edge of shallow local stream swollen by storm. It was heading upstream (east)..

I've seen a 6ft 2x4 come out a month ago but tonight, dark shapes emerge at my meet in the fast moving swollen current and i wasn't prepared for the undulations and turbulence as they churn the water and surface...probably two otters.
There is rarely any water in it.
Swimming by the Lifeboat Saving Station and standing briefly on the underpart of the dock on which was used to roll the boats onto the water.
On the dock.
Spotted at the lake a few days after major storms. The lake belongs to a homeowner's association. Spotted very close to trail but trail is not heavily used at this time due to flooding.

I saw the otter emerge from one of the storm drains that feeds the flood control canal and go swimming down it a ways before disappearing into a thicket along the shore.  I was very surprised to see it and by the time I thought to try to take a picture, it was too deep into the mass of plants to see.
It was swimming under a small pedestrian bridge along a bike path.  It was so cute!!!

Swimming and eating on both sides of the pedestrian bridge. Food appeared to be crunchy-- could hear the crunch when the two otters would come up for air to chew. The two otters swam towards the east end of the lagoon after about 10 minutes.
Otter was seen swimming towards east end of the lagoon. Came up to chew on crunchy food at least 3 times before moving east. Undetectable after 5 minutes of observing.
Otters seemed curious, looked at me while eating something crunchy (shellfish possibly), and swam off towards the west end of the lagoon after 2 minutes of sighting.

The otter caught the surf scoter just where the Drakes Beach creek flows into the surf. It then had to drag the bird up from the beach (the culverts were in full flood) and over the paved path  that leads from the parking lot to the Drakes Beach overlook. It did so in spite of the path being lined with Saturday tourists.
The otter was crossing Arnold Dr from a reservoir at the farm towards a creek at the other side of the road.
Resident of Sausalito for 30+ years and had few sittings in Bay from deck but never this up close and personal walking on Boardwalk to ferry to work - ready a gift!

I've just finished a short research paper on River Otters and was hoping I would see one at Abbott's Lagoon, and lo and behold, I did! It could have easily been missed, as it just came up to catch a breath, and then back under. I kept watching the subtle ripple of the water to follow it until it was out of sight.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - East Fork Swede Gorge Creek, March 4, 2017
properties.Notes: My cousin saw it jump into the water, then we observed it swimming down the creek.  There haven't been any sightings up the creek where we were, so I'm pretty excited.

The otters were feeding in a man-made pond about 50 yards from a creek that eventually flows into the Petaluma River and SF Bay.  They spent about two weeks in the pond, fishing for crayfish, usually in the early morning.  I've worked next to the pond for 20 years and have never seen otters there before.
Creek - flowing strongly following heavy rains. Lots of mud along steep embankment. The otter was swimming upstream, but in and out of water. It appeared healthy and strong.
This fish the otter was swimming with was about 1/2 the length of the otter and wash struggling the whole time before the otter disappeared.
Observed a lone otter swimming.
At the breach of the railroad bed at bivalve.

River Otter ran across 4 lanes of busy Guernville Road. But this usually VERY busy Hwy was light in traffic. The Otter made it safely across all lanes and started down the embankment towards the creek.
It's a long straight stretch of riprap, at a moderately high tide.  The otter didn't seem alarmed by people, although he/she kept moving along ahead of us.

I've been kayaking and picking up trash in EBMUD reservoirs for the past 5 years.  This is the most substantial evidence I've seen of a sustainable colony.EBMUD Reservoirs are stocked with fish through fees paid by California State Fish and Game fishing permits.  First there were birds....then came animals.....  A lot of spy hopping, creek crossing, tusselling, playing....not a care in the world....except for the guy in the kayak.....who was picking up trash from their new home.

First Yerba Buena Island sighting apparently, I'm very excited this discovery led to me learning about this great research project going on.  2-3 sets of tracks crisscrossing each other along Clipper Beach on Yerba Buena Island.
Fresh water lagoon adjacent to the ocean. I was on the road about 50 feet above them.
Swimming east then going under a tree recently fallen into the creek. They did not come out while I was there.  By the noise they made and after watching them, I would say they were mating.

The Otter was walking on the ground by the tennis court back-gate. When my daughter and I got closer s/he ran into the culvert drainage pipe below the sidewalk. The pipe is large in diameter and leads to the reservoir, Lake Cascade, which is on the opposite side of the tennis courts.

A large pond with fountain and reeds in one portion with island in middle. After playing, sliding on banks, otter swam out to island and ran around and slid down the bank there.  No clue how the otter could get up here. Orindawoods is on a hill and the pond doesn't seem linked by a stream. Perhaps a culvert? The otter was obviously having a grand old time. I watched it run around, slide and swim for about 15 minutes because I was incredulous at what I was seeing.
It was standing near the road by the lake, it then turned around and walked back into the water.
I only saw it swimming.
Lake Anza - northern part of Eastern shore. Swam back and forth for about 15 minutes. Was clearly interested in me and my dog.  Approached and vocalized twice. Did not leave the water
It was a wonderful way to start the new year!  It was clearly an otter, playing and rolling around in the water and then climbing up the bank and disappearing into the underbrush.
First watched the otter from the beach, then later from the bridge.
I saw a dead river otter in the road at Nicasio Resevoir in the west bound lane.  When I came back at 7 ish, the river otter had been removed from the road and I didn't see it anywhere.
In the water surfacing and rolling, then coming on shore and into the reeds.
It popped out from under a rock outcropping and looked at me for about 10 seconds and then swam back under the rocks.
Shallow water next to the bulkhead and public shore line.  River Otters have been around here quite a bit, but this is the first time we have seen or heard them mating in our 12 years here.

Riparian habitat. Flood control channel that was once the natural streambed through Chico.(Sandy Gulch)  It has been dry since the drought with some flow in the winter. Currently this is the most water that has flowed here in 6 years.   First river otters have been spotted and my family has lived in this house along the creek  for over 60 years.  One of the pair of otters is missing its left eye.
The creek receives run off from flood irrigation of almond orchards, so there is, often, more water in the creek in summer than spring or late autumn.
The creek receives run off from flood irrigation of almond orchards, so there is, often, more water in the creek in summer than spring or late autumn.

We first saw the otter swimming slowly right alongside the edge of the concrete at the front of the reservoir.  It swam about halfway down the length of the reservoir.  Then it turned around and swam very swiftly back about halfway, porpoising the whole way.  It was neat watching her leap out of the water every few feet like a porpoise.  Then it caught a large fish, and I thought she was going to eat it in the shallow water right there.  Instead it took the fish and swam back to a dense area of reeds by the shoreline.  It disappeared and I am thinking that she must have pups hidden there.  We could not see her once she was in that area.
I saw the river otter while hiking the Lost Coast Trail. He was voraciously devouring a fish on the beach. There were creeks nearby. I did not look for tracks or latrine sites.
Frolicking in pond. Left slide mark on narrow shoreline before reenterong water and swimming to downed tree.

I observed an otter with his head above the water carrying something in his mouth,(fish?), swimming about 15-20 ft  from  the shoreline , swimming toward Point Benicia . I followed him about 100 ft but he was swimming quickly and disappeared .
Dead on freeway. On either sider of the freeway there are ponds and remnant wetlands. I suspect the otter was crossing the freeway from one to the other.

This was the cutest Otter ever.  We were the only people we know of at the Lake - the Otter came to where we were walking and seemed to be talking to us.  Stayed around for about 5 minutes until our dog scared it away.  I could not find any other siting on Lake Anza!  We have been walking the lake for years and this is the first time we have seen an otter!

At the Larkspur ferry terminal.  It swam into the little east-west ferry parking channel just north of Corte Madera creek.  I watched it slithering around on the rocks and eating for about 10 minutes.  When I last saw it (as the 7am ferry was pulling away) it was swimming west towards the large ferry building/parking lot.  A great way to start the day!

This is my first river otter sighting in the 17 years I've been here.  They were enjoying themselves and seemed to know where they were going next.  Maybe they are frequent visitors.  This is the towards the end of Richardson Bay.  The Audubon Island is directly across, so they may have decided to wade across (it was low tide) to the dock.  They then walked towards my neighbors yard and disappeared into her shrubs.
It was sunning itself on the side of the canal. Pretty far from source with fish in it.

Bull Frog Creek estuary, where it opens into MMWD's Alpine Lake,, on the far side from the trail, swimming past the spot where a line has been rigged for turtle traps. No trap was present.  I was observing turtles through a spotting scope.  On both occasions, the otter was swimming towards the lake itself, and both times dived before I could pick up my camera & get a picture. Someone else has reported a muskrat in the general vicinity, but I have seen lots of river otters (mostly at Abbotts Lagoon or on Lagunitas Creek below Peter's Dam), and a fair number of muskrats (admittedly often skinned at Lexington Market), and I can tell the difference.  I could see no evidence of otters on the trail side of the estuary.  The far side of the estuary was too far away to see evidence of much, but I have often been to that location and never seen evidence of a slide over there.

Two unverified sightings at Muir Woods:Tues May 2 otter seen for 10-15 minutes mid-day below Bridge 2, swimming a bit, coming up on bank...Friday May 5   otter seen moving upstream from Bridge 1...10 am

Locked boat docking (building). Outside of gate and surrounding area is a steep slope. I've noticed big holes in hill, den??? Lots of cats and raccoons.  Big otter! Never seen one before, i was very excited!! It jumped on dock, slid a bit and seemed to pose?! My presence was obvious but otter wasn't too shy until I got to the gate. My boyfriend thought it was a pitbull (he was in his truck not a good view lol) but. It was cool!

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Mt View Sanitary District, May 17, 2017
properties.Notes: Along the fence line of MVSD and Shell Oil near car bridge.  This otter has an injury to her left eye.

properties.Description: 1 Otter - Mt View Sanitary District, May 20, 2017
properties.Notes: This is the one-eyed otter.

In my driveway. I heard crows going crazy so looked at my kitchen window (from there, I see my apartment driveway, then 2 yards from there, a fence, and over the fence a parking lot and a nail shop). One crow was on the fence, where they are usually not (they usually hang out on the nail shop roof), screaming, and that's when I saw the adult river otter, racing on the driveway, going from where we park our car (left side of the window) to the street (right side of the window)...Time for me to gather myself, close my mouth (that dropped looking at the otter running as fast as it could) and grab my phone in hope to take a pic or a video, I ran to the street and it was gone, but the crows were still yelling at the street corner.Now that I think about it, the otter might have been in the apt complex since yesterday morning, as the crows were going crazy then too.Poor thing, I hope it'll find the creek again and not get ran over by a car...!
